TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer again to the electoral fraud perpetrated on the Australian people at the last election when Mr Keating promised the l-a-w tax cuts, no new taxes, the removal of all pensioners from the income tax system, and non child-care cash rebates for all. Now that the true deceit of these promises has been laid bare for all Australians to witness, will you rule out the introduction of any new taxes such as a carbon tax, a hotel tax, an airline tax and a further rise in personal tax through the introduction of compulsory superannuation payments?

—The government has made it perfectly clear, through statements by the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance, that we do not rule out certain revenue options. We are not in the business of identifying with any precision at all at this stage what those particular options might be. Obviously we want to keep any taxation increases to an absolute minimum, for reasons that have been spelled out fully and thoroughly by the Prime Minister. We want to place the primary emphasis on outlays reduction and we will do so.

PARA.TAB: But in contemplating what revenue options are available to us, it is important to appreciate that we are genuinely one of the lowest taxed countries in the OECD, notwithstanding some highly selective alternative versions of the reality that have been recently published, including in the Financial Review this morning. We do have the second lowest tax burden in the OECD after Turkey, with lower taxes than certainly Japan, the United States and Britain. Total tax revenue as a proportion of GDP in 1992 was 28.5 per cent for Australia; it was 29.4 per cent for both Japan and the United States, and 35.2 for the United Kingdom. That is looking at the total tax burden.

If one wants to talk about the tax burden, I think it is appropriate to contemplate what exactly was the record of this particular lot opposite when they last had a chance themselves to do something about the tax burden on the Australian people. If we look at government revenue now under Labor as a percentage of GDP, we see that the figure is 24 per cent. If we look at government revenue in its totality under Howard as Treasurer in the period 1982-83, we find a figure of 26.1 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President, on the issue of relevance. The question clearly concerned the Labor Party promises at the last election, the promises that Keating made to the people. The question asked whether the Labor Party proposed to stick to those promises—in particular the promise that Mr Keating made that there would be no new taxes. What value, Senator Evans, a Labor Party election promise?

—We made perfectly clear that there was no such promise—it was for no tax increases as a percentage of GDP and that was made abundantly clear on a thousand occasions. PARA.TAB: Tax revenues as a percentage of GDP under Howard in 1982-83 was 24 per cent; under Labor at the moment it is 21.8 per cent. The top marginal tax rate under Howard was 60 per cent; under us, 47 per cent. The bottom marginal tax rate under Howard was 30 per cent; under us, 20 per cent. The company tax rate under Howard was 46 per cent; under us, 33 per cent. The taxation of dividends—double taxed under Howard; there is an imputation system under us. This is the reality of our commitment to reduce taxes. It is reduced as a proportion of total revenue. The taxation percentage itself is reduced. Every marginal rate is reduced. Company tax has been reduced and we have introduced a system of imputation, as distinct from the double taxation of dividends which applied under you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twelve years ago.

You imposed a tax system which was a burden upon business. We have relieved that burden. You imposed a tax system that was a burden upon ordinary taxpaying people of this country. —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer the minister to the opening last week in Chicago of an Austrade investment promotion office, run under the portfolio's investment promotion program. I understand that this is the third such office to be established in the United States, with others operational in New York and San Jose. Can the minister inform the Senate how this new office will contribute to investment promotion activities in the US? Does the opening of this office in the US reflect significantly an increase in interest from North America in investment options in Australia?

—It does reflect significantly on increased North American interest in investment in Australia. One of the functions of my portfolio is to promote both domestic and international investment in Australia. Last Wednesday, His Excellency the Australian Ambassador to the United States, Don Russell, opened an Austrade office in Chicago, Illinois. This Austrade office has as its key role investment promotion in the mid-west of the United States.

PARA.TAB: Austrade is, of course, part of the portfolio of my colleague the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan. My portfolio has contracted Austrade to deliver the investment promotion program on behalf of the Australian government. It is a good example of the two portfolios working very closely together.

In Working Nation last year, the government announced that it would extend the network of investment promotion services in the world. We announced a new office, which we opened in October last year, in Singapore and we announced this office, which we have now opened, in Chicago. The Chicago office is headed up by Mr Terry J. LaRocca, who was formerly the international marketing manager for Asia for the Illinois Department of Commerce.

As the question implied, we now have three investment offices in the United States—in New York, San Jose and Chicago. The Chicago location was chosen because 170 of the Fortune 500 companies are located within a 500-mile radius of Chicago. That is the region this investment office will be serving. Of course, the mid-west of the United States is the backbone of the industrial element of the United States economy. It is in that region that we will be seeking investment for Australia.

The reason for the prominence of the United States as an investment promotion target for Australia is that the United States is, obviously, still the world's largest source of foreign direct investment. While it dipped a few years ago and fell off the No. 1 spot, the US is now back as the leading source of foreign investment in Australia of all other countries. Therefore, we are concentrating our efforts there.

The investment promotion program has been outstandingly successful. We have attracted a number of regional headquarters to Australia. Some have been relocated out of Asia to Australia because of the benefits of being located here. Some 94 regional headquarters have been located here over the last period.

The investment promotion office will be drawing to the attention of United States business and commerce reasons for Americans to invest in our economy, such as very high growth and very low inflation. We have maintained a scenario of high growth and low inflation, which is indeed an outstanding achievement in terms of the world investment community. We also have high growth in jobs—nearly half a million jobs. We will deliver on our election promise of creating half a million jobs one year before our term is due to expire. So we will have done that early. It is a good achievement.

Investment itself is growing in Australia, as we know. The 14 1/2 per cent forecast in the budget is now around 25 per cent—an outstanding performance. That the tax levels in Australia are the second lowest in the whole of the OECD, certainly lower than the tax burden in the United States, is another reason why investment is flowing into this economy. These good, positive selling points for why foreign investment should come here are supported not only by the government in this investment office but also by a whole raft of Australian businesses who support us in these endeavours. —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister will be aware of increasing speculation about the possibility that the worst drought on record is about to break. In some cases this speculation reinforces the myth that drought ends with the first sign of rain. There have also been suggestions that the federal government's exceptional circumstances drought funding to rural families will end when the drought ends. Can the minister advise the Senate whether this is the case?

—I am aware of those perceptions and, of course, primary producers, farmers, find them very frustrating in that, as soon as you get the first fall of rain, people immediately say, `Well, the drought's finished.' It clearly is not. I think with all those people, certainly those who have been dealing with me over the last 12 months, one of the things they will not do is try to put some sort of green gloss on what in fact is a dry paddock.

PARA.TAB: But we do have to acknowledge that there have been good rains. For the first time in 12 months, and I am finally getting a little hopeful, the experts from the met bureau—and these days weather forecasting is becoming increasingly more accurate—are saying that there are real hopeful signs now, in terms of a reduction in the southern oscillation index, that we may have returned to more normal seasons this year.

I opened the ABARE Outlook `95 conference this morning. I was pleased to see that there were a huge number of delegates—well over 1,200; there is a lot of interest in this conference. ABARE will be providing information to the conference later this week that farmers can expect a significant boost to their incomes and production in the next financial year should the drought actually break. ABARE expects our major cropping industries to recover more than 50 per cent of the production lost this financial year. I am sure all coalition senators will join us on the government side in hoping that will happen.

The perception, however, still seems to exist amongst certain sections of the community that rain immediately puts an end to drought and that the federal government's drought assistance scheme finishes at the same time. In both cases, that is not correct. One of the important changes that was made in the drought package that was brought down last year is that a statutory period of six months was introduced so that the exceptional circumstances payments will continue after the exceptional circumstances declarations are lifted. Of course, farmers will have access to interest rate subsidies under the normal rural adjustment scheme beyond that.

The fact is that the number of farming families who are in receipt of the DRP has now exceeded 8,000; there are 8,206 families receiving the drought relief payment. They will continue to receive such payments for a full six months after the exceptional circumstances declarations are lifted. The approval rates for applications are now running at around 88 per cent.

There are also misconceptions—and this must be said—on the farming side of the community about eligibility for exceptional circumstances. The true English meaning of the word `exceptional' has to be attributed to it; the circumstances have to be exceptional in order to receive these payments.

I know that people and farmers in some areas that are drought affected are concerned that they are not getting these payments. The reason is that an independent assessment has shown through RASAC that these are not exceptional circumstances for these areas.

At the ABARE conference this morning, there was an organised protest—and fair enough—by members of the New South Wales Farmers Association; the reason I know that is that the conference labels on their coats said that. The protest was about why farmers in the Hay region—they were from Hay—were not getting this payment. I said that it was because they had not been considered eligible and I would double-check it. When I did double-check it, I found out that not only had RASAC not recommended it but the New South Wales Farmers Association itself, in all of the submissions it made to me, and the New South Wales government, in the two formal submissions it made to me, did not recommend that exceptional circumstances should be extended to Hay or to the farmers in the southern region.

It is important to correct both of those misconceptions. These payments will continue. The drought is not over because the rains have come, and the payments will be made only to those farmers who are assessed as being in exceptional circumstances. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to his statements on the Radio National breakfast program with Peter Thompson this morning. How does he explain the obvious inconsistency between a position recognising Indonesia's annexation of East Timor while at the same time continuing to profess support for a process of self-determination for the people of East Timor? Does the minister believe that Australia has ever really pursued or campaigned for a process of self-determination for the people of East Timor? Will Australia now move to repeal the 1989 Timor Gap treaty, to genuinely work towards a process of self-determination for the people of East Timor and, when that is achieved, to negotiate a Timor Gap treaty which would give a fair share of the profits back to the Timorese people?

—There is a lot of misunderstanding about the concept of the right to self-determination, which it might be helpful for me to clarify at the outset. The right of self-determination of peoples is recognised in general terms in the UN charter in articles 1 and 55, but I think it is fair to say that it has always been a very imprecise concept. It is presently subject to quite a lot of international rethinking, particularly because of the proliferation of claims to self-determination by national entities within larger sovereign states, as distinct from the more familiar colonial context. It is worth acknowledging that at the outset.

PARA.TAB: The question of what self-determination means in any particular case and how it might be exercised in any particular context is a matter to be pursued by the United Nations. There are a number of UN resolutions on this subject, and they make it clear that self-determination can involve a number of quite different outcomes, including of course the emergence of an independent state, but also integration, or some form of association within or with another state, or a degree of autonomy within another state. I think that is important background.

In the case of East Timor, Australia recognises that the people of East Timor do have a right of self-determination—to choose, in effect, how they are governed. This has been Australia's position since before the events of 1975, and it has never been reversed. The UN, in relation to East Timor, has certainly recognised that there can be no solution to self-determination and related issues without the cooperation of the Indonesian government; thus the consultations with Indonesia which are now being conducted under the auspices of the UN Secretary-General and which Australia fully supports, and has done since their inception.

As to the question about inconsistency, Portugal argues that Australia cannot both recognise Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor and, at the same time, say that the East Timorese have a right to self-determination. Senator Bourne seems to want to embrace that Portuguese claim of inconsistency. The situation is that before 1975 Australia recognised Portuguese sovereignty over East Timor while, at the same time, simultaneously recognising the right to self-determination of the Timorese people. There is no difference between the situation then and now. A claim of a right to self-determination can exist with a recognition of sovereignty. We recognised Portuguese sovereignty then—and, in fact, up until 1979 before we formalised it—and since 1979 we have recognised Indonesian sovereignty, but we have also recognised right through that period the right to self-determination by the people of East Timor.

As to the Timor Gap treaty, which Senator Bourne wants us to repeal, it is important to realise, because this too has got lost in the argument about this case, that Australia negotiated the Timor Gap treaty not to gain access to anyone else's resources but to our own share of the resources of the Timor Gap area. Australia could not do that before the treaty because there was no agreed international boundary line in that area. As Indonesia was in control of East Timor, Australia had to negotiate with Indonesia to settle the boundary issue.

Portugal cannot seriously pretend that it is now, or has been since 1975, in a position to give effect to an agreement on the Timor Gap. I have to say that generally, whatever might have been the situation before 1975 or before 1979, we simply do not accept that, in 1995, Portugal, the colonial power which governed that territory so lamentably and ultimately abandoned the territory, continues to have any right whatsoever over East Timor.

Finally, Australia has always tried to generate actual results rather than rhetoric for the people of East Timor. I have run out of time, but if you want to ask me how, I will tell you how in a supplementary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the minister's recent magical mystery tour of Cuba. —It is the case that some thoroughly confused reporting appeared in the media after the estimates committee hearing from a reporter who, despite, I am told, being thoroughly briefed, was utterly unable to grasp the distinction between a debt being written off and rolled over. The truth of the matter is exactly as I described it to Senator Kemp in the estimates committee hearings, namely the broad nature of the agreement that was canvassed during my discussions in Cuba and which I hope will be brought to consummation in a couple of months time is a result whereby the existing $17 million debt, a combination of capital and interest, would in fact be paid off—not written off but paid off, perhaps with some negotiated reduction as is common in these cases, but paid off—in order to clear the decks with EFIC. But it may well then be that a line of credit of an equivalent amount on a short term basis might then be established in order to enable the supply from Australia of other commodities much in demand in Cuba.

PARA.TAB: That is the broad basis of the agreement. That will be the subject of further discussion over the next few weeks and hopefully this will be resolved. It is an outstanding matter which has not been helpful to Cuba's commercial reputation in this country and is a matter which this government has made many representations about.

My visit to Cuba of course was not simply designed to address that particular issue. It was also designed to advance Australian commercial interests because there is a very substantial mining investment of some $400 million to $500 million presently being contemplated that we hope shortly will be brought to fruition. Moreover, there are a number of multilateral issues of some consequence that needed to be addressed. I refer to the issue of Cuba's constant cold war preoccupied obstruction in international forums of arms control and disarmament negotiations, and indeed an obstructive attitude that it takes on many other matters of multilateral diplomacy. In those circumstances it is important, through dialogue of this kind, to try to encourage the country out of that time warp.

Moreover, it is the case that Australia will be a candidate for the Security Council of the United Nations in 1996 and it is important to pay attention to what remain very influential members of the Non-Aligned Movement and the Group of 77 developing countries. It was in that context also that this visit was made.

A further point of the visit was to make some very direct representations to the Cubans about their human rights performance. I was prepared to acknowledge, quite frankly, that when it comes to a number of the economic and social rights, the performance over the years has been good, particularly in the context of health and education. I was also prepared to acknowledge that a number of the steps that had been recently taken towards opening up the economy, developing a marketing pricing system, opening the economy to investment and so on, are also much to be applauded in terms of economic freedoms of people within that country. But there is an obvious continuing problem so far as political and civil rights are concerned, rights to freedom of expression, rights to free association, and free elections. These are matters which continue to give concern to the international community. I took the opportunity of that visit to make some quite strong representations about those particular matters. The choice as always is whether or not to seriously address these areas of difference, of principle and practice and to seek to persuade; or whether, rather, to impotently, feebly and noisily stand off, hurling insults in the way that has become so characteristic of this opposition. I make no apologies whatever for the role that I played in relation to that particular visit, and nor will I ever.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.

SPEECH.PARA: Export Inspection and Meat Charges Collection Regulations (Amendment)Statutory Rules 1994 No 369

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee agreed that Monday, 23 January 1995 would be the last day for departments to provide answers to questions on notice relating to the committee's consideration of the 1994-95 additional estimates, and
(ii)the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) gave the committee an undertaking to provide answers in the Communications and the Arts portfolio as soon as practicable;

PARA.TAB: (b)expresses its grave concern that, in spite of the committee deadline and the ministerial undertaking, to date not a single answer has been provided to the committee relating to the Communications and the Arts portfolio; and

(c)resolves, therefore, that there be laid on the table, by the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator McMullan), not later than the adjournment of the Senate on 8 February 1995, the following:

TAB.TAB: (i)the answers to all questions on notice asked by the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee in relation to its consideration of the additional estimates for the Communications and the Arts portfolio, and
(ii)a document showing the dates that the answers to each of those questions were provided to the Minister's office by the department or relevant agency.

SPEECH.PARA: All these questions were put on notice on or before 29 November 1994. This means that Mr Lee has had over two months to answer them. On 30 January, the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee informed my office that it had been told that a significant majority of the questions had been completed and were awaiting the minister's approval. The committee set a deadline of 23 January for the receipt of these answers. Usually departments are given a month to answer questions on notice and sometimes even less for estimates questions.

PARA.TAB: I am told by the committee that all the answers have been received to questions on notice put to all other portfolios in the estimates hearings. There has not been one single answer provided from the communications and the arts portfolio. This is despite the minister writing to the committee saying that the answers would be provided as soon as practicable.

Usually answers are provided to estimates committees in batches. I understand that some answers may take longer than others. However, this minister's failure to answer even one question in over two months is a blatant and arrogant thumbing of the nose at the parliamentary process.

I wrote to the acting chair of the committee on 30 January expressing concern about this matter. The chair then wrote to the minister on 31 January conveying my concerns. That was more than a week ago. Despite this reminder, we are now told—as communicated to my office at around lunchtime—that only 10 per cent of the answers could be provided by tomorrow, 50 per cent by Friday and the rest by Monday, 13 February.

This is totally unsatisfactory. The committee is due to reconvene on Thursday, 16 February. Under the standing orders, the last day for reserving matters to be examined in the supplementary hearings is 13 February. How can we know what to reserve for the supplementary hearings? The only option is to reserve all matters that relate to questions placed on notice in the first round of hearings. This means that these hearings could go on for days.

It is not as if these questions are not of some significance. Anyone who looks at some of the questions that are on notice will very quickly appreciate that they are not simply point scoring questions. They are designed to elicit information which ought to be on the public record and which is very necessary for the formulation of broadcasting policy.

For example: why was the payment to the Public Broadcasting Foundation in support of ethnic news radio reduced from $1.9 million in 1992-93 to $140,000 in 1993-94? How much funding is the Commonwealth providing to subsidise the cost of modifying decoders to allow people in remote areas of Queensland to continue to receive ABC and SBS broadcastS? On how many occasions has the ABA examined whether Canwest's involvement in Channel 10 is in accordance with the Broadcasting Services Act? To what extent does Telstra enjoy a monopoly in relation to the operation and maintenance of National Transmission Agency facilities? How does Australia Post ensure that its non-core services, such as the sale of stationery through its retail outlets, remain financially separate from its core mail and parcel services? Which, if any, current Commonwealth funded programs and activities will be subsumed into the Gallery of Aboriginal Australia? How will Australian media enterprises finance the development and commercialisation of multimedia and interactive media products? Another question asked was: For each recipient of an Australian artist creative fellowship since its inception, please provide the purposes for which the artist claimed in his or her application the fellowship would be used and whether the stated objectives of the application were achieved.

Those questions go to the heart of the process of the parliament because, unless those answers are known, then this government is able to make do with propaganda churned out by Mr Lee on a regular basis—without being held accountable in any form, without being tested as to the merits of the propositions and without any questioning of government policy. That is tantamount to saying that we ought to simply ignore the parliamentary processes and allow the executive to get on with government. I have heard Mr Keating say that on a number of occasions, and I have no doubt that that is his view. In fact, I think as recently as yesterday he said something like, `The House of Representatives ought not to worry about the budget, and when it arrives in the Senate we ought to just give it a tick.' That is typical of the attitude of arrogance that is no doubt second nature to the Prime Minister. I am surprised that his puppet adopts the same approach; I would have thought he was trying to make his own way in the world.

Mr Lee has been notoriously slow in answering questions on notice and, in particular, correspondence. I have a number of examples of letters I have written to him over the last year which have either not been answered or which he has taken an inordinate length of time to answer. I wrote to him on 8 December 1994 making representations on behalf of the National Aboriginal and Islander Skills Development Association—no answer received to date. I wrote to him on 26 September 1994 urging him to consider including the four state opera companies in the proposed major organisations board—no answer. I wrote to him on 10 March last year requesting urgent attention and assistance on behalf of Hitz FM, a non-profit community youth radio station—again, no answer to date. I wrote to him on 7 June in relation to a large number of complaints regarding the telecommunications carrier special exemptions under the draft telecommunications national code—it took him more than four months to reply to that letter.

This minister has a long history of prior convictions for refusing to answer correspondence and for refusing to comply with requests from the committee. In those circumstances, we should treat the contact by his office with my office this afternoon as simply no more than an attempt to stall for no good reason. They have obviously had all the time in the world; they have had letters of request; the minister received a letter more than a week ago. Yet on we go.

Most ministers in this chamber make a reasonable effort and, if they are dilatory and are asked to explain their behaviour, then they often come in here and explain it—I suppose, mea culpa—and we accept that they are acting in good faith. I have no reason at all to think that Mr Lee is doing anything other than giving effect to the views of one of his staffers whom my office contacted some months ago and asked for information, and the reply was, `Why should we help you in any shape or form; your job is to get us.' I take that as truthfully reflecting the attitude of the office and no doubt the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Try contacting some of Kennett's staff and see how you go.

—I am not in any shape or form suggesting that the response you might get ought to condone the response from one of your colleagues. You have only got to listen to question time in the House of Representatives. You get these feeble little efforts on the part of Mr Lee to try to somehow suggest that our policy approach is not quite as good as his.

PARA.TAB: Not once has Mr Lee ever landed any blow of substance. It is simply an attempt somehow to flex some very small muscles. I find it not even irritating but virtually laughable. It is a concession on Mr Lee's part that he is floundering and cannot handle the heat of the political game. At the very least, when he has a massive bureaucracy behind him, I would have thought he would be capable of responding to questions on notice.

The summary of Senate questions on notice for 1994 also makes interesting reading. It makes the point that since Mr Lee became minister at the end of 1993, he has been asked 66 questions on notice by senators relating to the communications and arts portfolio. Of these questions he has answered a mere 10 questions within the 30-day time limit set by the Senate. Answers have taken 107 days, 156 days, 186 days, 140 days, 148 days, 106 days and 130 days—the last still remaining unanswered to date.

That is a pretty appalling track record. I would very much like to hear whether there is any explanation or justification. I have no doubt at all that Mr Lee would do a lot better if he applied his mind to these matters. Obviously he does not regard the parliamentary process as any sort of priority. I have to say that he would be one of the worst performers in that regard. The only conclusion I can come to is that he is running scared because he knows that the questions that have been put on notice will expose a number of deficiencies in his approach and will probably involve him in a lot more work as well. Well, if he wants to be paid for driving around in a big fat car, then here is his chance to earn his money.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that the parliament gets the information that it seeks and that it gets it in a timely manner. But we are now talking about whether getting all the material by Wednesday is fundamentally different from getting it all, some by Wednesday, some by Friday and the rest by next Monday. That is the substance of the matter.

PARA.TAB: Let me deal with Senator Alston's speech. I did my best to listen to it and, unless I missed something, I failed to hear him mention how many questions there were. The fact is that he did not give that information because the facade of reasonableness would collapse when it became apparent that we are talking about more than a thousand questions. The answers that are being sought are not one or two or 25. There are a thousand questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are on the minister's desk now. They have been answered. He won't release them. Get your facts straight.
—That has nothing to do with the point. The point is that there were a thousand requests.
—They have been on the minister's desk for weeks.

—If Senator Tierney wants to get excited, if he wants to do something about his blood pressure, let him do it somewhere else. I am trying to speak about the issues that are before the Senate. The fact is that we have a person here who studiously avoided providing the facts against the background of an outrageous proposal involving a thousand questions to be answered over December and January. That task requires a huge collective administrative effort across several bodies within the communications portfolio. The minister, as do I think all responsible ministers, does not regard himself merely as a conduit of the department but rather as the person who provides the answers. I do. When answers come from the department to me, I seek within the limits of my capacity to check the answers myself. I do not just say `Here they are' and pass them on. That is the proper process. PARA.TAB: Contrary to Senator Tierney's enthusiasm, my understanding is that the minister has not received all the answers as yet. He is currently examining those answers that have been forwarded. Senator Alston has acknowledged that he was advised of the minister's proposal, and his understanding is the same as mine. The minister's proposal was that, notwithstanding the mountain of material involved, some 10 per cent of the answers can be provided tomorrow—which does not sound a lot, until you realise that it is more than 100 answers—approximately 500 or more can be provided by Friday, and the remaining 500 or so can be provided by next Monday.

The Senate may pass a resolution that the material the minister does not have has to be supplied by tomorrow. The Senate is a very powerful body, but it cannot make things exist that do not exist. It cannot make documents be tabled that have not been provided. It is the sort of squeeze that ministers in this place get caught in from time to time. In this instance that is not the case. But in a motion of the same nature, requiring the minister to provide something that, as I understand it, has not been provided to him is a rather difficult task.

I make it very clear that there is no intention not to answer the questions. All the questions will be answered and they will be answered quite promptly from here. But you need to appreciate that, if you ask 1,000 questions, it will take a little longer to answer than if you had asked 100 questions. If you do not have the capacity to set priorities about the matters of which you are concerned and you seek to ask every question, then it will take longer than if you were not so slothful and set priorities and asked key questions. Most senators, and particularly most shadow ministers, take the trouble to do that. If you are slothful and say, `Here are all the questions everybody ever thought of about this issue,' it will take a while to get the answers. But to have the so-called nine weeks, including the week between Christmas and New Year, when I suspect not a lot of answers were processed—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the other eight weeks?

—I would like to compare that with the amount of time you were putting in and being diligent. The point is that there were 1,000 questions. I am advised that all 1,000 questions will be processed by next Monday. That is a reasonable proposal. That is the information. The Senate can pass a resolution saying that it all has to be provided by tomorrow. I am not sure what will follow from that, given that, as I understand it, the minister does not have some of the information requested. We have to calm our enthusiasm about whether or not somebody is trying to defy the Senate. We will have 1,000 answers by next Monday. If that is an unreasonable proposition, then I am sorry. It seems to me that the Senate will get all the information it wants, and it will get it within two sitting days of the date specified in the motion.

—I rise to support my colleague Senator Alston on this outrageous matter of delay to answers to questions. I will deal with Senator McMullan's rather feeble excuses in a minute. What this demonstrates yet again is a curtailment of the powers for scrutiny of the Senate. In the chamber yesterday, on the Procedure Committee report, Senator Hill outlined a number of ways in which Senate power and the rights of senators to cast this government under scrutiny had been curtailed. We have here today yet another example of this in the delay in providing answers to questions. The end result of what the government has done is that the minister is now giving senators—with their very limited staff, as opposed to ministerial and departmental staff—very little time to actually look at these answers and work out responses to them.

PARA.TAB: Since I came into this place four years ago, we have witnessed—in addition to this curtailment of senators' rights, as Senator Hill said yesterday—changes in hours. We have seen changes in the amount of time senators can speak. We see increasingly, particularly since we have changed Presidents of the Senate, the rights of senators in this place to ask questions and to have matters taken note of in response to points of order severely curtailed. This has given the government a free run.

One of the great dangers to parliamentary democracy is the fact that we have in our system a tendency towards centralisation. You have the executive arm of government having an increasing amount of power. It leaves the members of parliament fighting battles on two fronts. First of all we have to try to get the government to come clean and to give us honest answers in this chamber. But then we have to fight on a second front against public servants who will not come up with straight answers to questions in estimates committees.

There were many examples during the time Senator Alston and I were looking at the matter of the ABC. Senior public servants would sit there, go round and round in circles and never give you a straight answer. I asked the head of a department, when we were at a dinner in Canberra, about this and why we could not get a straight answer out of the Public Service. He said, `You've got to ask the right question.' In other words, we that are generalists are not experts. They are the public servants. They know what we are getting at. They know the answer. Instead of coming clean and saying, `Look, this is the situation. We'll give you the true and full picture,' what tends to happen is that they sit back and wait. If we do not ask the precise question that gets to the exact point, they will try to skirt around it.

We had an example with the ABC and its core activities and its non-core activities. I asked the secretary to the department seven questions before I got him to admit that, on the ATV matter, if their debt kept blowing out and the government really decided in the end that it would not continue with that activity, the money would not come as a supplement out of the Department of Finance but it would have to be met out of ABC funds—in other words, out of core activities. He did not say that up-front at first; it took about seven questions before we got to an answer.

Senator McMullan made much of the fact that there are 1,000 questions. What Senator McMullan is forgetting is that there are about 10 different departments and agencies in this area of communications and the arts. That averages out at about 100 questions an agency. I would have thought that, with these areas of government that have massive resources, answering 100 questions was not beyond them. The sorts of questions we put on notice tend to be ones which require factual information and should be easily found in government documents and other reports.

The problem here was not that they did not have enough time. They obviously had enough time because, even with Christmas, these matters have been on the minister's desk for some time. Senator McMullan said that they are not all answered, and that is probably right. But why has he spent quite a lot of time just sitting on those matters and not passing them through to senators' offices? In the end, he is putting us in a position where we do not have proper time for scrutiny. That is a great pity.

I remind the Senate that the area under consideration is the Department of Communications and the Arts. This is one of the crucial areas in the future development of Australia. We have had the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) bring out a special policy and special budgetary supplementation to really help kick us off in areas like the information superhighway. For example, in the United States seven per cent of GDP is now in the communications industry. It is a large part of the future growth of Australia and the health of our economy is going to depend largely on developments in this area; yet constantly there are problems. Last year we had the example of pay television. The responsible minister at the time, Senator Collins, absolutely messed up the pay TV arrangements because he did not read documents. We had a major inquiry and an internal inquiry into the operations of the department and found that they were grossly deficient.

Looking past the central department to the various agencies, like the ABC, our recent inquiries show a huge number of problems there also. When we asked the departmental head, `How does this area come under scrutiny on behalf of the public?,' he said, `The Auditor-General looks at it.' That is fine up to a point. That will do something to look at the financial management of the institution, but it does not look at what it is actually doing in terms of fulfilling a charter, for example. There needs to be far greater scrutiny in this area because these agencies are not just parts of the Public Service; they are statutory corporations.

We are dealing here with massive areas of public investment. We are dealing with the ABC, which has over half a billion a year, Telecom, which actually makes a profit of $1 1/2 billion a year, and a range of other agencies in telecommunications, culture and the arts. There are a lot of areas that need scrutiny.

When these matters come before this parliament, the parliament is treated in a very shabby way, not only through the estimates process but also by the reports of this department. Senator Alston will recall that on one day at the end of last year, 11 reports in the communications and the arts area were presented on one day. As senators are aware, the Senate has half an hour to consider these reports—five minutes for each speaker. That means that six senators can speak. Even if everyone wanted to speak on communications, we would not get through half of the report. We are competing for time with every other department's report as well. I think on that day there were about 38 different reports to be considered. This is yet another example of this government's trying to avoid scrutiny.

The government should not be doing that in this particular case. It has had the material since the end of November. It has had eight weeks to look at it. Some of this material has been sitting on the minister's desk for up to two weeks, I believe. This government stands condemned for yet again trying to avoid the scrutiny of the people's representatives in the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a position of the government to attempt on all occasions to answer questions on notice, both in the normal process in this chamber and via the estimates committees. That is a desirable principle and ministers try to adhere to it. Senator McMullan has less power in this regard for a department that he is not directly responsible for. It is always easier with your own department than it is with someone else's department.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tierney made what I think is one of the most outrageous statements I have heard in this chamber when he said that the power of this chamber is going. —I am not taking credit for it. I am talking about the powers of the Senate. Why don't you clean out your ears and listen? I am talking about the powers of the Senate. You said that the power of the Senate was being eroded over the years and I am saying that that is patent and absolute nonsense.

PARA.TAB: If this chamber accedes to notice of motion No. 1330, it will be completely out of control. This government will under no circumstances comply with that particular notice of motion. Those opposite are not in a position to dictate to executive government when it will decide issues such as the 509 coupes. We have given a timetable of two weeks and under this other notice of motion they want to do it within five days. Well, it is physically not possible to do so—

TALK.START.PARA: —Eight weeks.

—I am talking about notice of motion No. 1330 and the powers of the Senate to say that that would be excessive. I am coming back now to compare this lesser motion with a lesser demand in it, but I was using the comparison.

PARA.TAB: The second point we make relates to the number of questions put on notice. Sometimes these create problems with any bureaucracy, none of which have magical powers in getting the answers in a set time. I always ask my department to try to avoid taking questions on notice. I say, `You are there at the estimates committee. You should have some expertise. Try to answer questions for the senators. Never mislead, but only answer the question asked—that is natural. But try to put the answer down there because in the end you are giving yourself immense hard work.'

TALK.START.PARA: —We tried to do it with aNiMaLS.
—Senator Kemp interjects. When he was a ministerial staffer for Senator Guilfoyle, would he have responded to a call from a Senate committee? Never. Yet he expects this to occur on this occasion.
—But my salary was not justified on giving out government information programs.
—He never would have appeared in his life.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! Senator Kemp!

TALK.START.PARA: —He attacked me!
—Senator Kemp! Don't you argue with me.

—I won't let the great distracter distract me. A number of questions become a factor. Secondly, you can get struck with questions on notice that are absolute nonsense. I had to put up with this this time in Defence, not from your group but with questions that had absolutely no connection with each other and that had all sorts of prejudicial assumptions in them—
—Who from?

—From Senator Margetts. And we were supposed to go away and try to address those questions seriously. That was very hard. Unless we accepted all the assumptions in the questions on notice, we found it very hard to answer them other than in a desultory way, which we do not want to do. We want to give correct and proper answers. But if the questions are prejudicial, are not based on fact, are based on guess work or are misunderstanding of the budget process, it is very hard to answer them.

PARA.TAB: The second very difficult area is that of historical questions, which we are getting more of. That is where you do not ask about what the department has done in the last year but ask us to go back and research five to eight years. My attitude is that if that process is too complex and it costs too much money, I will not do it. I will say, `This costs too many resources to attempt to do because it is not relevant to the current year's expenditure.'

The next hurdle that often delays answers is that of answers having to be cleared through the relevant minister. No-one in this chamber would suggest that you send the questions across to the department, bring the answers back and send them straight to the committee without looking at and checking the answers, because sometimes departments make mistakes. Sometimes you are able to pick up those mistakes and have them corrected in the answer. Sometimes a few slip through, but most people cut a bit of slack there and understand that no-one is perfect.

I come to the point of cost. There is a view, I think, amongst some senators that you can put hundreds of questions on notice and that there is no cost in answering them. Last year I costed the activities of one senator in relation to putting questions on notice. It went well into five figures. This year someone is going to pass that by a mile. That is a cost to departments. It is a cost of effort. It does divert officers sometimes. So a lot does go back.

What is the nature of the questions? They usually fall into two areas. Some are Senator Alston or Senator Tierney seeking information to help them in their public life—that often happens—and some are simply a trawling exercise. Questioners throw the long line out to see what they can hook. They might ask 500 questions and get one fish on the end. That still has a cost to it.

I point out that here we are dealing with additional estimates. Ministers have been very liberal in their interpretation of the questions they have been asked, but all have tried to answer them in one form or another, at the committee or elsewhere. But this is additional estimates. The questions should be to do with the additional money being spent only. Yet if you go back and have a look at the questions asked at the estimates committee and by way of notice—I am only guessing now, but I bet I cannot be proved wrong—you will see that quite a few of these 1,200 questions are not to do with additional estimates—

TALK.START.PARA: —A thousand.
—I thought there were 1,200, but there were going to be 1,000 answers.
—Rampant inflation.

—It must be a bit of inflation. All right; I accept my colleague's correction. A thousand questions. How many of those were on additional estimates? Those opposite don't know and I don't expect them to respond, but would I be wrong in guessing at least 50 per cent were not on the additional estimates process? Nevertheless, in the tradition of flexibility of this place, ministers try to get answers because if they do not do it this time they will probably get asked next time. So why not do it? It is sensible public policy.
—The answer is that you don't get the annual reports in time.

—You didn't get them in time when you were in government either, did you? You rail about the processes in the upper house and responses of the government. Yet in New South Wales and South Australia, where you do not control upper houses, you rail against minorities or oppositions dictating, et cetera. You have no consistency whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: In fact, when John Hewson went to the last election, one of his great pleas was, `Give us a Senate majority.' All those points of interference that you call scrutiny and I often call scrutiny are sometimes just plain, blatant political interference. You do not want it done to you. You want a fair run. That is one of the reasons, when you did get the majority to increase the powers of the Senate, we put it in standing orders rather than sessional orders—so that you people could not ignore it the moment you won government, because that was your intention. You always go soft on Senate procedure, powers of the Senate, powers of committees and all the rest of it close to an election. You always go soft on it. I have seen that from Senator Hill and former Senator Chaney.

I want to put one other matter on the record. If, in fact, this Senate puts timetables on answers, it may well affect the quality of the answers, for one reason and one reason only. I want to take you back three years when this happened to me as Minister for Defence. We were asked a question, I think on notice, about asbestosis. It is a fact in the navy. An officer of my department went to a lot of trouble to prepare an answer. He did not, however, check the records back to 1942 when this was first mentioned.

One of your colleagues came in here and had him referred to the Privileges Committee for misleading the Senate. This chamber carried the motion to refer that employee of the Department of Defence, doing his job, trying to get the answer right, to the Privileges Committee. We had a debate on that but no-one listened. Everyone made up their mind beforehand. When the Privileges Committee looked at the issue, of course it found absolutely no guilt and dismissed the charge against him. The point I want to make is that, if you have deadlines and you rush public servants—I am not saying in this case—and you rush answers and then you do not like the answers, you should not take the poor officer to the Privileges Committee. It is just not fair.

I repeat that governments have to go through the process of estimates committees. Whilst none of us like it at times because of its irrelevancy and, on occasions, its stupidity, it is still a good committee process of accountability. There is no question about that. It is probably the best process in government, along with the Auditor-General, so we do not want to knock the chocks from under it in any particular way.

I can remember serving on estimates committee C. I can remember attending nine estimates committee C hearings, seeking information from the then Fraser government and from the then Minister for Finance, Senator Guilfoyle, and having it refused on eight occasions. Maybe we did not have the commonsense to put in returns to order and all the rest of it. Maybe we did not.

TALK.START.PARA: —We always try to cooperate, Robert.
—That is right. It was eight meetings—six hours of meeting.
—I can remember Richo just giving blanket refusals to any questions asked in certain areas.

—Can you? I am glad you can remember something. I can remember a lot of things, too. I can remember when you used to have the Melway out looking for a House of Representatives seat. Maybe you should go back to it.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to finish on is that the process of answering questions on notice should be complied with where it is practical. There is no dispute on our side on that. There is no dispute whatsoever. For those who say that this is an absolutely simple process of putting a thousand questions in and getting a thousand answers out the other side, the deadline that you set cannot always be met, depending on the complexity of the questions and what the questions go to. We, on this side, believe we should try to get those answers in as quickly as possible because I think it suits our own self-interest to do so rather than having all the material regurgitated at the supplementary hearings. It is not always possible in every circumstance to get every question answered in a timetable that suits you. It is simply not possible.

We should retain the system where ministers clear answers. We should retain the system where public servants are at least protected. If you want them to go in haste and they make a mistake, please do not hold them responsible. Hold the minister responsible; do not hold the public servants responsible for a mistake that may be made trying to get you a quick answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I am indebted to Senator Ray for his contribution because in more than 10 minutes I do not think he, in any shape or form, attempted to argue against the merits of this particular case. I will just deal with a number of the points.

PARA.TAB: The fact is, Senator Ray, that if you were genuine—and you purported to be genuine—about the desirability of answering questions, if you were fair dinkum, you would demonstrate your bona fides by providing answers progressively. You have had 70 days to answer a lot of questions from 10 different senators. If you were serious, when you were written to by the committee, as you were seven or eight days ago, you would have written back and said, `Well, the fact is to date I've had a lot of questions. I've managed to get through two-thirds of them. Some of them are still requiring further information, but this is what I have got to date and you can have that.'

Of course, I suspect the real reason why we have not got any answers at all is that Ken was overseas for the whole of January swanning around Europe. Of course, if he only got back at the beginning of last week, he did not give himself much of a chance to deal with what, no doubt, he would regard as a low order of priority. So, completely of his own making, he finds that he has all these questions piled up in his office and, because he prefers to run around Europe on vacation, he has not had time to do the work. Again, if he were genuine about all of this, he would have written back and explained where we were in the process and not come up with possible explanations transmitted through Senator McMullan.

As Senator Ray rightly said, one cannot hold Senator McMullan personally at fault in this exercise because, quite clearly, it is not Senator McMullan's fault. Senator McMullan is here responding on behalf of Mr Lee. That is where the blame resides. It was quite open to Senator McMullan to transmit a message from Mr Lee's office that, indeed, a number of these questions were fishing, vexatious, frivolous, irrelevant. All sorts of objections involved an enormous volume of resources and covered historical matters. We could have had all of that. If you were serious and genuine, you could have come in here and given us those sorts of reasons why it had not been possible. But we did not hear one word along those lines. There has been no attempt to suggest that the government has had problems.

As Senator Ray says, it is desirable to get answers as quickly as possible. It is not possible to get all the questions in time. We have not had any questions at all, so you have to ask yourself: what is going on here? I think one explanation is that the minister has been too busy. He put his personal preferences, going to the other end of the world, ahead of his parliamentary responsibilities.

Then, as you would know if you have been around this place for any length of time, there is also the other very transparent and utterly predictable strategy behind all this. I just noticed it on the ABC committee, for example. We have put down questions on notice, and each and every time those answers turn up a couple of hours before we are about to start the hearing. It is the oldest bureaucratic trick in the book. Quite clearly, Minister Lee has decided that he will deliver only half the answers to these questions from a range of senators. They have to go through them immediately on Monday, irrespective of what other commitments they might have, and, by the close of business on Monday, communicate to the secretary of the committee whether they have any further questions arising. Clearly, they have to consider all of those answers and their adequacy in a matter of a couple of hours on the Monday before they can then indicate, as they are entitled and indeed required to do, whether they want to take the matters further. It is a pretty transparent ploy, I would have thought.

You have had 70 days to provide answers. You have provided none. You did not even, in response to the minister's letter, attempt to contact my office, for example, and provide any sort of explanation or attempt any sort of negotiations. You rang up about lunchtime, knowing it was coming on after question time, and you put forward this proposition: `It is all very demanding and we can't possibly comply. Here is our offer.' It is not much more than an ambit claim. It is not much more than pretty grubby, bureaucratic politics.

I do not blame Senator McMullan personally for this, although I would not like to say that he would be above doing that because I think it is pretty much standard practice on the other side that, wherever possible, they give the opposition as little time as possible within the general rules. That is what I think is going on here. This is a conscious and deliberate attempt to squeeze the process to the very end in order to minimise the amount of extra work. As I say, if we had received a number of these answers to date or if there had been any attempt to indicate that somehow the questions were unfair, too demanding or simply covering utterly inappropriate ground, one might have thought that we would have heard of that by now or during the course of Senator McMullan's response—but we have not.

Therefore, I think there are only two conclusions we can come to: firstly, that the minister, by his own actions and in choosing to be out of the country for about six weeks, has put himself in a difficult position; but secondly, and most importantly, he has made no attempts since that time—and I suppose he could have had the material faxed to him on the ski slopes or wherever he was, but he has not even done that—to come up with anything except simply an eleventh hour proposition which is very much along the usual lines of trying to put maximum pressure on. In those circumstances, I hope that the Senate will carry this motion in order to demonstrate that we do expect ministers to comply.

I would say one thing finally: what we are asking is that the minister comply with a resolution of the legislation committee of 23 January. That committee had a majority of government members on it; in other words, they all took the view that the minister had had ample time to answer the questions—and he has chosen not to. He has made no attempt, since 23 January, to come up with any of the answers. All he has done is wait until five minutes to midnight to come up with some sort of feeble tactical response. That is not good enough.
