TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS) is provided with $1.5 million of public funds,

(ii)although the purpose of the NMLS is said by the Government to be the dissemination of Government information, it appears to have the real purpose of monitoring the activities of the non-Government parties for political purposes,
(iii)the Government's legal advisers have concluded that NMLS is not subject to performance audit by the Auditor-General under the Audit Act,
(iv)the Auditor-General, in a special report to Parliament, drew attention to the situation in the following terms:

NMLS is therefore not subject to the normal accountability mechanisms in place over Government programs. As a consequence, although NMLS is fully funded by the taxpayer and its stated roles and functions are predominantly administrative in nature, its operations are not subject to the scrutiny normally associated with the expenditure of public monies;

(v)the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) refused to allow the Director of NMLS (Mr David Epstein) to appear before the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee during its hearings on the estimates to answer questions concerning NMLS, on the ground that Mr Epstein is a ministerial staff member, and
(vi)the previous Director of NMLS (Mr Colin Parks) appeared before a Senate estimates committee;

PARA.TAB: (b)instructs the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee to hold a supplementary estimates hearing, on or before 24 February 1995, to hear evidence from Mr Epstein concerning the expenditure of the public funds provided to NMLS, and to report to the Senate on the results of that hearing; and
(c)directs Mr Epstein to appear before the committee at that hearing for that purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of this matter goes back to the tabling in the Senate of the Auditor-General's report, Audit Report No. 17 of 1994-95, entitled National Media Liaison Service—a loophole in accountability. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall that the ANAO decided to conduct an efficiency audit of government information and advertising. For the purpose of conducting part of the efficiency audit, the ANAO contacted the National Media Liaison Service. Without going through in great detail what happened precisely in the weeks following that contact, essentially the National Media Liaison Service did not respond to the Auditor-General's request to be allowed to conduct an audit. Ultimately, the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Walker, wrote that the proposed review was ultra vires.

PARA.TAB: In his short audit report which was tabled in the Senate the Auditor-General made a very valuable point. He said:
NMLS is therefore not subject to normal accountability mechanisms in place over Government programs. As a consequence, although NMLS is fully funded by the taxpayer and—

SPEECH.PARA: and I stress this—
its stated roles and functions are predominantly administrative in nature, its operations are not subject to the scrutiny normally associated with the expenditure of public money.

In a sense, the government has conceded that this is a real problem in relation to the National Media Liaison Service because we read in paragraph 1.7 of the Auditor-General's report that it is expected that agencies such as the National Media Liaison Service will be covered under the new Audit Act in the regulations which will be brought before this chamber. The first point I would make is that we have a government agency—the National Media Liaison Service—which, according to the Crown Law Department, is not subject to the normal efficiency audits one would expect to be carried out on an agency disposing of such a large amount of government money.

PARA.TAB: The next step in this history relates to the estimates committee hearings which were held last Friday and at which Senator McMullan attended. I gave ample notice that I wished to ask some questions about the activities of the National Media Liaison Service. These questions had been asked before. Indeed, the Director of the National Media Liaison Service had, in the past, appeared before this committee. I have previously quoted an instance when in 1989 Mr Colin Parks was prepared to come before this committee and answer questions. I repeat: I gave ample notice that I wished to proceed and ask some questions relating to the National Media Liaison Service.

When the committee resumed on Friday, Senator McMullan was sent in to open the batting. He said that the questions which I put to him should all be put on notice. Of course, this is quite contrary, Senator McMullan, to the very line that Senator Ray was putting to this chamber just some minutes ago as to how governments attempt to respond to questions rapidly and accurately, and how much better it is that those questions are put to the estimates hearing directly rather than on notice. So I played by the rules of the game, Senator McMullan. I indicated that I wished to ask these questions.

Senator McMullan comes along and presents a letter from Mr Beazley which, in short, indicates that the Director of the National Media Liaison Service, Mr David Epstein, is not to appear before the committee. What is the result of this? I asked a series of straightforward questions of Senator McMullan: what is the budget of the National Media Liaison Service? Senator McMullan, `Put it on notice'; what are the objectives of the National Media Liaison Service? Senator McMullan, `Put it on notice'. So it proceeded. It was a total and absolute farce and it continued for over an hour. Senator McMullan was clearly pursuing a strategy, which had been worked out with Mr David Epstein and Mr Beazley, that no questions would be answered; these questions would be put on notice and carefully vetted before any response was given.

The government has a real problem here. It attempts to justify the expenditure of $1.5 million of taxpayers' money for a government information unit. The purpose of that unit, as set out in the material tabled some years ago by Senator Bolkus, is that it provides accurate and timely information on government policies. That is how the government attempts to justify the employment of 23 officers of the National Media Liaison Service; their job is to provide information on government policies. In fact, there is a sensitivity that somehow this unit should not be used for party political purposes; in other words, the $1.5 million is to be provided in order to promote government policies and programs.

Item (d) on the roles and function of the National Media Liaison Service states that `representatives will not work with local or state party branches'—and I stress this—`and will not be involved in party programs, nor electoral campaigning'. The government is careful to distinguish between the role of the National Media Liaison Service and the more political role that ministerial staff often perform.

The government justifies spending $1.5 million on a unit of 23 officers in order that this unit can promote government policies and programs. But when the Auditor-General tries to assess the work and performance of this unit—along with various other bodies that carry out government information and advertising programs—the walls are put up. Then when the Senate estimates committee appropriately seeks to ask questions about the role of this unit, again we have stonewalling and Mr David Epstein gets a note from the teacher saying that he does not have to appear. The government attempts to justify the $1.5 million spent on government information programs, then it hides behind the fact that Mr Epstein and his colleagues are employed under the MOPS Act and, therefore, according to Mr Beazley, are not subject to questions by the Senate committee. The government is trying to have it both ways.

The problem is this: if the government said, `We employ 23 officers at $1.5 million, and their job is to carry out political work on behalf of the government doing research on the opposition and putting out material on the opposition,' the government would have to provide Senator Kernot and the opposition with additional staff to do similar work. But, of course, it does not want to do that; therefore, it says that this is a government information program.

I believe that the government has been comprehensively caught out here. This does not establish any precedent that ministerial staff will be called before Senate committees. I give that assurance to Senator McMullan. This says that, if a government sets up an agency to carry out work on promoting government programs and policies, that is what it should do. We are entitled in this chamber, therefore, to assess how that work is being carried out, as is the Auditor-General.

What everybody in this parliament knows—with the sole exception of Senator McMullan when he appeared before the estimates committee last Friday—is that Mr David Epstein is not carrying out the function which is specified and which taxpayer dollars are being provided for. Mr Epstein is carrying out altogether a different function and directing his staff—I suspect, therefore, improperly—to carry out an alternative function.

To summarise it briefly, this unit is a political hit-squad. We understand from the media that much of its work is designed to carry out research and analysis of the political opponents of the government—the Greens, the Democrats and the coalition. That is the dilemma that the government now has. It has justified spending $1.5 million and justified employing 23 officers right around Australia on the basis that they are carrying out work to promote government programs and policies. That is why this Senate committee is perfectly entitled to ask questions about the work of this unit, and that is why this Senate committee is perfectly entitled under our standing orders to summon Mr David Epstein to appear before the committee to answer these questions.

There is no precedent being established here—except the precedent of accountability. That is the precedent which is being set, and the Auditor-General has indicated that there is a major loophole in that area. As I said before, this unit is justified by the government as being an information unit on government programs and policies. The government attempts to make it clear in the guidelines governing this unit that it is not to involve itself in political work.

I suggest that, when Mr Epstein appears before this committee, Senator McMullan should be there. If Senator McMullan feels that questions are unfair or that he would prefer to answer them, Senator McMullan will certainly do that—like ministers do when other officers are called before these committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know you are giving assurances, but he is still on the ministerial staff under the MOPS Act.

—Senator Kernot, I pointed out that he is a ministerial staffer under the MOPS Act, but the government justifies the expenditure on his salary by saying that he is not performing the political work of a ministerial staffer, nor is he attempting to dig up dirt on the Democrats or the opposition; he is performing work to promote or provide information on government programs. The Auditor-General has pointed out—it is not me saying this—that there is a major loophole in accountability in this program.

PARA.TAB: In the roles and functions of the National Media Liaison Service, item (d) says that representatives of the unit `will not be involved in party programs, nor electoral campaigning'. The sort of question that the Senate committee wanted to ask Mr Epstein was whether he was involved in any way during the last election campaign. That is a fair enough question. You justified spending the money on the basis that he and his 23 officers would not be involved. We are entitled to see what sort of work Mr David Epstein and his colleagues carry out.

The government is on the horns of a great dilemma here. It justifies spending $1.5 million on the grounds that this is a unit to promote government information and government programs. Then when we seek to inquire what Mr Epstein and his colleagues are doing in carrying out that work, the government suddenly ducks for cover and runs behind the MOPS Act. If Senator McMullan wants to be frank and say, `Mr Epstein and his colleagues are really doing party political work and the work of ministerial staff,' that is all right. You say that, but then the problem is that you have to justify why you should have additional staff for political work, and the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens are not granted a similar facility. That is your problem.

I put it to you that there is no precedent being created by this motion. There is a major problem, which the Auditor-General has carefully identified and brought to the attention of the Senate. The estimates committees are perfectly appropriate committees to examine the work of the National Media Liaison Service. Therefore, I urge the Senate to support this very reasonable motion which will ensure proper accountability.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sensitivity involved on the opposition side is clear from the number of times Senator Kemp said that there is no precedent being created here. I accept that he has no current intention of using the step which he is taking as a precedent. But I am not absolutely convinced of his capacity to resist the temptation to do so. Let us think about what a precedent is. A precedent is something done for the first time which others may subsequently use to justify similar actions in the future. That is exactly what this is, without attributing any motives to Senator Kemp other than those which he has articulated. It is a dangerous precedent.
—Mr Parks appeared before the estimates committee.

—You know my view about that. It is a dangerous precedent for the Senate to summons somebody. That is a very different question. Perhaps you do not know that, Senator Abetz, but Senator Kemp does. The fact is that some important questions have been raised. I do not deny that. The audit office is an important principle of our system of accountability, as is the parliament and the estimates committee system. Both those things are true.

PARA.TAB: For anyone who is listening to this debate or who subsequently reads it, let us get one thing clear: the normal financial audits that apply to the proper expenditure of taxpayers' money to ensure that there are no misappropriations do apply, and always have applied, to the expenditure of this money. What we are talking about is whether the current law allows a performance audit of the National Media Liaison Service to be conducted.

It is not a question of a ministerial edict saying it should not be conducted. The advice of the Attorney-General's Department is that it is ultra vires the act as it now stands. If the Senate does not like that, then it is open to it to deal with the legislation when it comes before it, as it is about to do as we all know, to ensure that that problem no longer exists. I do not want to get into the question of interpretation as to whether the bill, as it is now drafted, does do that. That is another question. If it does do that, you can keep it as it is and if you are worried it does not do that, then you can amend it. The proper processes exist for dealing with that.

The enthusiasm of the opposition for performance audits of bodies such as this was not evident in the days of the Government Information Unit which it ran when it was in office at a much greater cost to the taxpayer, and which displayed not only blatant evidence of its partisan activities generally but also blatant evidence of its partisan and active activities within the Liberal Party. This was properly more of a problem for the then member for Kooyong than it was for us at the time.

Why are the constraints that set down the role and function of the NMLS phrased as carefully as they are? We learnt the lesson of the abuses conducted by the Government Information Unit under the Fraser government which operated at a much greater real dollar cost to the taxpayer than the NMLS has ever cost. Is that ever acknowledged? No. Was the opposition ever enthusiastic about questions of accountability then? No. Let us not have any of that humbug. If the question of a performance audit of a body such as this is appropriate—I will come to my view about the appropriateness of at least some part of it later—then the legislative route is the way to go and we will, by 1 July this year, have in place a process to resolve that problem.

The question is: should the Senate resolve to require a ministerial employee to appear before a Senate committee, and where might that slippery slope lead us? It is not a question of whether the government is prepared to answer questions about NMLS. It may be frustrating for Senator Kemp, Senator Abetz and others to have to get their information on notice, but get it they will. It will be provided.

The Senate will get the information that it has sought and, to the extent that it is within my power—and whatever you might think of my other performances, I think in this area my record is okay—it will be as prompt as I can make it. I am not the minister directly responsible, but it will be as prompt as I can make it. Notwithstanding previous resolutions, I am pretty happy to stand on that record. I will seek to get that as promptly as I can. I hope to be able to provide you with the information on those things that you asked for on Friday very soon. I do not know whether it will be all of it because I have not checked the list—I will do that before I send it—but certainly you will get a substantial amount of it.

If there are other matters that arise from that and you want to get some more information, I will seek to supply it as promptly as I can. It is not a question of whether I, as the minister representing the minister responsible, should have to provide the information. It is a question of the accountability of ministers to this parliament, which I will seek to uphold.

Who comes to assist me in the provision of that information? If you want to ask questions about the behaviour of people within the department, you might have to put them on notice. The information can be provided without calling a member of ministerial staff before the committee. In my view, ministerial staff are accountable to the minister and the minister is accountable to the parliament and, ultimately, the electors.

That is how the performance audit is conducted on all of us. The performance audit of all of us is conducted by the voters, and so it should be. That is the way the representative democratIndustry Commission system operates. Ministerial staff are accountable to ministers, who are accountable to the parliament and, ultimately, you are not a minister if you do not get the support of electors. There is nothing special about ministers. It can equally apply to anybody employed by the opposition, minor parties, government backbenchers or ministers. This is a matter to which this parliament should give serious consideration.

It is important to remember that Mr Epstein is not only the Director of the National Media Liaison Service but also—I do not have his title clear, but I will happily provide it because it is no big secret—the head of the Ministerial Media Group. He is the head of the Ministerial Media Group which is a very straightforward ministerial staff function, not dissimilar to that function conducted by any member of parliamentary, ministerial, opposition frontbencher or parliamentary office holder staff.

What are the issues? The first issue is: should there be a performance audit of functions conducted by people under the MOPS Act? My view is that there should not be. I am not sure whether that is the view of the government. I think it is getting the accountability equation back to front because it means that you can then have the executive scrutinising the parliament. It is not supposed to work that way. The government could have a performance audit of the opposition. That is absurd in my view. The outcome might be absurd too, but that is another question. That was not my point.

I think that is a wrong principle. I think that you should not make that decision. I think you should think very soberly about that. It does not matter what you think about me, David Epstein or the NMLS; I do not think you should make that decision. If you do think there should be performance audits of ministerial staff, then you should fix up the legislation to ensure that that occurs. Secondly, I do not think the performance audit issue arises here. Nothing in this motion will resolve it even if you are concerned about it.

Thirdly, we need to ask whether the parliament is entitled to information about actions taken at ministerial direction and the spending of taxpayers' money within the normal parameters of the things that governments have never answered such as cabinet-in-confidence matters and all those sorts of things. I am not trying to create a new principle here. The answer is obviously yes. To the extent that I can—often on notice—that information will be provided to the committee. As I said, that was done last Friday and we will seek to do it again.

I do not think we should proceed to create what Senator Kemp may not intend as a precedent. I do not impute a motive to him beyond that which he has said. But it clearly will be a precedent some day, some time, in a way that causes serious problems for the parliament and its relationship with the executive. In a sense, it will probably enhance the executive vis-a-vis the parliament, but I am not sure that it will do that in the way that it should. It may enhance the position of the government vis-a-vis the opposition, but I am not sure that it will do that in the way that it should.

I simply say that this is not a step you should take on some sort of whimsy or because you think open government sounds nice and sounds like it ought to happen. The information should be supplied within the normal caveats we have always had. As I said, I am not trying to erect new ones or take down the old ones. I am working within the standard procedures of what is supplied and what is not. The question we need to ask is: who should be called before the parliament to supply it? I do not think this is the appropriate course of action, and I hope that the Senate chooses not to take it.

Senator Kemp has given assurances about no precedent being set. I agree with Senator McMullan's observation that Senator Kemp was at pains to repeat it so many times that it has become a point of sensitivity. I know that I raised it with him myself. We should be careful about this. I know Senator Abetz interjected that Mr Parks has appeared previously.

As Senator McMullan alluded to, there is the problem of the parliament and its relationship to the executive. We usually talk about our desire to question the executive, which is a legitimate function of the parliament. However, I point out to the government that it does not seem to have taken any action on the Pearce report, when we looked into the processes surrounding the allocation of tenders for pay television licences.

One thing I remember so clearly from that report is the questions raised about the demarcation of responsibility between ministerial staffers and public servants working in the department. It is a very grey area. It is something that this government needs to address in terms of structural reform. That may be the way out of the dilemma we have whereby the government is saying that the National Media Liaison Service provides a service to government while other members of the Senate are saying that it seems to be serving a party political purpose in that ministerial staff cannot be required to answer questions.

I suspect that the way forward is some sort of restructuring from the government and some sort of demarcation and delineation of the purpose of both these groups. I personally think it is very legitimate to follow public comment about matters under ministerial portfolios. Ministers have a legitimate entitlement to know what is being said. Other senators have made a distinction between that sort of activity and party activities being funded through taxpayer money. Senator Kemp wants to ask questions about the NMLS role in the last election campaign.
I guess we have to ask whether reconvening the estimates committee is legitimate. Does Senator Kemp have hundreds of questions?

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I think it will be quite a speedy process.

—He says that it will be a speedy process. I do not have the solution. While in the draft audit bill there is some suggestion that performance audits of the National Media Liaison Service are a possibility—I agree that they should be—that is different from the principle of requiring a ministerial staffer to answer questions.

PARA.TAB: I feel very uncomfortable with the Senate taking this step. We have seen from experience here that once something is done, irrespective of the assurances given—I acknowledge Senator Kemp's assurances—people with other motivations can always point to the precedent. Down the track, who will remember the facts of this debate and the assurances that were given?

We are going to support the opposition, but with grave reservations about what we are doing, which I want acknowledged on the record. I personally believe that the government would be wise to look at the Pearce report and find some way of sorting out that blurred area of responsibility between ministerial staffers and public servants working in departments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a brief contribution to this debate. I will commence by commenting on the analogy used by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) when he referred to the road that we are going down in relation to this motion as being a slippery slope. The National Media Liaison Service is suffering from the greasy pig syndrome. You think you have caught it, but each time it slips out of your hands. We are dealing with a greasy pig rather than a slippery slope.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Robert Ray so eloquently put it to the Senate in the previous debate, the Senate estimates committee and the Auditor-General are two key elements of accountability by the executive to the parliament and, through the parliament, to the people of Australia. He spoke somewhat condescendingly. Nevertheless, he made the points very well.

In relation to the history of the National Media Liaison Service, commonly referred to as aNiMaLS, we as an opposition have been trying to get information. First of all, the Auditor-General independently sought to make an investigation into efficiency. He was blocked by the minister. Whilst I accept that the legal opinion was that it was ultra vires, the simple fact is that nothing was stopping the minister from saying, `Although there is a legal technicality, we welcome the Auditor-General looking at the performance of the National Media Liaison Service as part of our overall review in the particular area of government advertising.' So the government took the particular decision not to allow the Auditor-General in.

What was the next step? The next step was the estimates committee. Senator McMullan's performance on Friday was, with due respect, not too flash. Most of the questions were answered by `I will put it on notice' or `I have no idea'; basically we were given non-responses. That was very frustrating, especially when we heard in the previous debate a senior minister, Senator Robert Ray, indicating how he seeks to instruct his department to give open and full answers at the actual hearing. There seems to be a different standard applied by the government in relation to the Department of Defence under Senator Ray from that applied in relation to the National Media Liaison Service.

Being a suspicious opposition, I think it is appropriate for us to ask why Senator Ray adopts such an open attitude to the Department of Defence at estimates committees but the minister responsible, Senator McMullan, seems to have taken a bunker mentality in relation to answering questions about the National Media Liaison Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't understand his point at all.

—I understood Senator Ray's point very well, Minister. The point was that estimates committees and the Auditor-General provide the best process of accountability and the National Media Liaison Service, like the greasy pig, has slipped through both of those processes. It is therefore unfortunate that this matter has to come before the parliament and before the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I say to you, Minister, that if you are concerned about the dangerous precedent that is being set—I have to say that I accept what Senator Kernot said and it is a very dangerous precedent—the interesting thing is that a precedent has been set previously; namely, by Mr Colin Parks, who appeared before the Senate estimates committee voluntarily. If you were to have followed that precedent, there would have been no need for this motion before the Senate today. One can only ask the question: why is it that you did not want Mr Epstein to follow the precedent set by one of his predecessors, Mr Colin Parks?

It is interesting that Senator McMullan, as is the typical Labor ploy of late, went back 10 years or more to the Fraser era. It is amazing that he did not go back to Alfred Deakin and the founding fathers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Robert Menzies on your side.
—Or, indeed, Mr Menzies, as I often interject. What happened so long ago bears no real relevance to what ought to be happening today.

PARA.TAB: It was interesting that throughout the debate there was no real attempt by the minister to defend the role of aNiMaLS, to defend the $1.5 million of taxpayers' money that we allege is being spent, to defend the fact that it has 23 staff, or to answer in any way the history of denigration that this organisation has had to suffer at the hands of people like Senator Kemp, others in the opposition and me. It seems strange that the minister did not want to get in to that area of debate to justify that this is an area where public moneys are being well spent.

The simple fact is that this question is one of accountability and it is an area that clearly ought to be dealt with by this Senate. Albeit, it might be setting a dangerous precedent but that was as a result of the minister and the government taking decisions not to allow the Auditor-General in and trying to frustrate the Senate estimates committee process. Senator Kernot mentioned the fact that the new audit bill, which will take effect as of 1 July this year—

TALK.START.PARA: —The regulations.

—Yes, will possibly have some effect in this area. Her colleague Senator Coulter—I think it was last week—made a very interesting point that the efficiency audit would be by regulation and therefore, undoubtedly, the regulation could be effected by the minister as well determining the regulation. That is something that I am not on top of at the moment but I am flagging it for the Senate's attention as possibly an area that we need to look at when we as a Senate consider the audit bill that will be coming before us shortly.

PARA.TAB: The Hansard of Friday, 3 February 1995 from the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee from pages 20 through to 32 would indicate to anybody who would want to read that Hansard that questions asked by Senator Kemp, Senator McGauran and me were simply not answered in a way that one would expect of a government that is committed to the concept of accountability. As Senator Kemp highlighted—I think it is something that needs to be highlighted again—when the minister was asked how much public money is spent on this service he was unable to answer; he had to put it on notice.

I would have thought that when dealing with estimates committees and accountability the first question the department and the minister would have on their mind would be what is the overall budget—how much is spent on salaries, accommodation, support staff, et cetera. None of that information was forthcoming at all. Of course, when we were confronted with such a response after the government's nearly panic performance over not wanting the Auditor-General to look at aNiMaLS, we as an opposition clearly had no alternative but to take the course that Senator Kemp has so responsibly set in train and, hopefully, the Senate will support.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Senator Kernot raised a number of matters, the principal one relating to her concern about a precedent being established. I certainly give the assurance that in no way can a precedent seem to be established by this.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan put in a pretty lacklustre performance in this debate. I do not think he wanted to be here. He made no attempt to justify the activities of the National Media Liaison Service. He did not query any of the complaints which have been made against that service. He did not attempt to argue against the fact that on previous occasions I have made the point that the National Media Liaison Service is not acting as an information unit dealing with government programs but often directs its activities into digging up material on the opposition and acts, as I have said before, as a political hit squad. Senator McMullan made no attempt to argue against those points that were made in the debate.

Further, there are, like so many difficult political issues, matters of clashing principles. A key principle is the accountability of government for its programs. The Auditor-General has pointed out that there is a loophole in accountability. The second principle is that where a government says it is spending money in a particular area it is appropriate for this Senate, through its estimates committees, to test whether that money is being spent in that area or is being spent on some other purpose.

I thank Senator Kernot and her colleagues for the constructive way they have approached this debate and the way they will be voting. I hope the Senate can now pass this motion and we can speedily deal with a matter that should have been dealt with last Friday; namely, the activities of the National Media Liaison Service and what it has been doing with the very substantial amounts of taxpayers' funds which are provided to it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 1330 standing in the name of Senator Ian Macdonald for the tabling of documents concerning forest coupes be taken as formal.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice and at the request of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill), I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1330 standing in the name of Senator Ian Macdonald for this day, relating to an order for the production of documents by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) concerning the assessment of forest coupes.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak a little uncertainly because I am not quite sure exactly how this motion will be dealt with by the different parties. The Labor Party is obviously totally opposed to it. Senator Faulkner will no doubt speak for himself, but he tells me the reason the government is not supporting this motion is that that information is not available.

PARA.TAB: Why I sought that information was based on last week's statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The Prime Minister said in his statement announcing the resolution of the forestry dispute, particularly for the people outside Parliament House:

SPEECH.PARA: . priority attention will be given to resolving the status of those coupes which meet all three of the following conditions . . .
Those conditions are set out in my motion. Then the Prime Minister went on to say:

Following consideration by officials from the Departments of DEST, DPIE and PM&C, and consultation with the relevant State Departments, next week Cabinet will consider the status of these coupes, with a view to the statutory decision maker, the Minister for Resources, making a final decision . . .

So on 2 February Mr Keating said that next week the government would start looking at each individual coupe. What I have asked for in my motion before the chamber today is not that we get those assessments. I am not asking for those assessments. I want Senator Chamarette and Senator Bell to be clear on this: I am not asking for the assessments; I am simply asking for those particular coupes to be identified. The assessment process will take place this week. Mr Keating said last week that it would take place `next week'. That must be this week, so he must have them identified already. I will not accept Senator Faulkner's statement that the government has not identified those coupes. How can you start the process of going through each one if you do not know which ones they are?

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating must have known on 2 February which coupes they were. I want him to let the Australian public into that. I want Mr Keating to tell the Senate and the Australian public which coupes they are. I think it has been suggested in the newspapers that there is about 70. He knows them. Cabinet is going to start looking at them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not mean to interrupt the flow, but we can probably expedite things. I think technically we are still on the motion for suspension of standing orders.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Yes; you are right. Senator Macdonald is speaking on his motion to suspend standing orders and has a couple of minutes more, as required by standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it might therefore be useful to allow the suspension and the next formal motion. Then Senator Macdonald can continue his remarks on the motion itself. This would expedite things for everybody. The only reason I did not suggest this earlier was that I was waiting for Senator Faulkner. Senator Macdonald, I am sorry to have interrupted you, but let us get those motions through.
—On that basis, I will not say anything more.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Ian Macdonald, on behalf of Senator Hill) agreed to:

That general business notice of motion No. 1330 standing in the name of Senator Ian Macdonald for this day, relating to an order for the production of documents by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) concerning the assessment of forest coupes, may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business this day till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That there be laid on the table by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), not later than 5 p.m. on 8 February 1995, the following:

SPEECH.PARA: the description and location of the coupes included in the 509 coupes identified for priority attention, which meet all three of the following conditions:

TAB.TAB: (i)are currently being logged in accordance with their licence conditions,
(ii)have licences which were renewed in 1994, and
(iii)are not registered as part of the National Estate, and

PARA.TAB: as promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his statement on the timber industry of 2 February 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not repeat myself but simply refer anyone who might want to read this debate later to what I started to say on the contingency motion. I will try to pick up from there: Mr Keating must have known or had a fair idea on 2 February which coupes they were. I am not, I repeat, asking for the assessments of those. They will be done this week according to Mr Keating. Cabinet will consider all of them. I want to know which coupes they are so that the Senate, senators and the Australian public can have a look at them.

PARA.TAB: I do not think I can reasonably take that matter too much further except to say that I think it is important in this whole debate that there be as much transparency as possible. The whole process has been an absolute fiasco from start to finish. The government is well aware by now that the timber people are unhappy, the environmental people are unhappy—everybody is unhappy—because the system has been a complete shemozzle, a complete shambles, a complete fiasco.

I am concerned by the way the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) and his department are handling this whole process. In an exchange that occurred relative to this same matter but on Senator Faulkner tabling documents which were demanded by the Senate in a previous return to order, Senator Faulkner clearly advised on 2 December at the time he tabled the contracts—if I could put my hand on the transcript I would quote it, but I cannot; I showed Senator Faulkner and also Senator Bell the transcript of Hansard where Senator Faulkner indicated this—that all relevant and contractual acquittal processes had been complied with.

Senator Faulkner then privately indicated to me that he was prepared to make that information available when he got it. He said—and he also said this on the public record—that now was not the time because the time by which that acquittal report had to be tabled had not yet arrived. Senator Faulkner wittingly or unwittingly—I give him the benefit of the doubt by saying `unwittingly'—has misled the Senate. For misleading the Senate, he should take the honourable course.

Minister, not only did you on 2 February 1995 say that all relevant acquittal obligations set out in the contracts have been complied with; today you said the time has not arrived. Senator, if you or your advisers would care to have a look at the contracts, I will take you through them to show you that the time in fact has arrived. On that basis, that acquittal report should be here. You have misled the Senate by saying the time has not arrived. It makes one wonder what the purpose of this exercise is if the Senate instructs Senator Faulkner to table some reports and then he is not prepared to comply with that.
Senator, so that in the cooler light of day you or your advisers can follow this through—although you have not been well treated by your advisers so far—the contract in clause 2.4(c) says:

SPEECH.PARA: A final coordinated report must be given at the end of the seventh week or by 4 November 1994, whichever is the sooner.

The relevant date for the final coordinated report is 4 November 1994. The final instalment of the payments to the contractors, to the conservation councils in this instance of $3,818, was to be paid on the completion of the contract. I would suggest that that is probably being paid on 4 November. Elsewhere in the contract it is made quite clear that the project has to be completed on delivery, and there must be written acceptance of a satisfactory report no later than seven weeks from the date of receipt of certain material from the department or no later than 4 November, whichever is the sooner. Again, this report had to be completed by 4 November.

PARA.TAB: Clause 5.3 of the contract says that within eight weeks of the completion of the project, or some other happenings, the grantee shall repay all unexpended grant moneys and provide an acquittal report to the department. The contract makes it quite clear that the completion of the project is no later than 4 November. Eight weeks from 4 November has certainly passed by now. It coincides with the advice that Senator Faulkner was given and which he mentioned to us on 2 February when he said that the four organisations have complied with all relevant acquittal obligations set out in the contract. Now he is telling me and the Senate that those acquittal reports are not here. Either Senator Faulkner is lying or these people have not complied with the contracts. In that event, I want to know why. Over $100,000 of taxpayers' money has been paid to four conservation groups to put in these assessments. We want to see, as custodians of the taxpayers' money, what we got for that $100,000 and who was the recipient of all the money.

I was flabbergasted in question time today when Senator Faulkner said that a lot of the information that these conservation groups provided in those reports was from a database. If it was from a database or from state conservation departments, why, Senator, didn't your department do that, at a very minimal cost, rather than pay these conservation groups $100,000-plus of taxpayers' money to do what your department could have done—simply call up the database of the state forestry and conservation departments—to get the information?

Senator, this web is a very tangled one that you and your department seem to have tried to create, but it is coming untangled very fast. It is becoming a matter of major scandal about what happened to that $100,000; what we as taxpayers got for that money; and why you cannot produce the acquittal report, which was supposed to be in by no later than 4 January 1995 and which, in spite of an order of this Senate to table the report, you tell me today you cannot table because the time has not arrived. The time has arrived, and you should table those acquittal reports if you have them. If you have not got them, you and your department are derelict in your duty by not enforcing those contracts and making sure that those people who received over $100,000 of taxpayers' money account to us for what they did for the money that was paid to them.

I hope that Senator Faulkner will curtail further more drastic action in the next couple of days of the Senate by explaining those things tonight. I can assure him that, unless we get a decent explanation on why those acquittal reports are not here, we will be bringing Senator Faulkner to account for his misleading of the Senate and for his incompetence and dereliction of duty in not enforcing the terms of those contracts.

Returning more directly to the motion before us, I again say to my colleagues in the other parties and groups in the Senate that the information on which coupes Mr Keating was referring to on 2 February—when he said that they were going to be assessed by cabinet in this current week—is important. We, as well as members of the cabinet, have the right to know which coupes he is talking about. It is obvious that on 2 February 1995 Mr Keating knew which coupes they were. I fail to see why anyone could object to senators being brought into the picture and being advised of which coupes they are.
In an attempt to save some further repartee later on, following a conversation earlier with Senator Chamarette—I do not think that I am giving away any confidences, am I, Senator Chamarette?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no idea of what you are going to say, so go ahead.

—Senator Chamarette indicated to me that she was not opposed to the motion before the Senate, but she did not like the timing of it. She indicated that, if I altered the date to the first day of the next sittings, she would support that. I am in the situation where I am not quite sure what the Democrats or Senator Harradine or Senator Devereux are doing—and that is my fault for perhaps not being as diligent as I should have been. If the Democrats will support us in seeking to have that information—which must be there—tabled by 5.00 p.m. on 8 February, then we will proceed with it. If the Democrats say that they are not going to be with us, I will take the second best option—with no offence to Senator Chamarette—of then attempting to amend my motion to include the first day of the next sitting.

PARA.TAB: I would hope that, having heard the argument, Senator Chamarette might be agreeable to allow the motion to stand. Alternatively, I would hope that Senator Bell might realise that by agreeing to the motion he is not putting the government to any particularly onerous task. It is information that the Prime Minister had on 2 February and should be available to us. It takes no-one backwards a step, except perhaps the Labor Party; perhaps it would make it look even more foolish and incompetent in its handling of this matter. In the real interests of the forest industry people and environmentalists, it is important that we are all let into the secret. I urge the Democrats and the minor parties to concede the motion so that we can get that information before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I sought your call at this early stage because I could see that Senator Macdonald was racked with anxiety and trouble about the direction of this motion. I hope to relieve some of that tension that he is suffering from. While I would not in any way seek to shelter the government from the scrutiny brought by this motion in its initial format, I share Senator Chamarette's concern that the date is a little hasty and that an amendment to seek a later date would place this motion to a closer representation of what it in fact is.

PARA.TAB: It is appropriately a question on notice. It is not a return to order, which is a device for the discovery of an existing document or documents. This motion is asking for the creation of documents or for the compilation or collation of existing documents into a format which is being asked for by the mover.

These things are normally done by way of questions upon notice and such a process allows fair time for such a collation. In fact, the Democrats have several motions on the Notice Paper at present seeking specific information but which allow sufficient time for an accurate answer to be given. That is as it should be if we seek to attach accountability to the government. We regularly follow that process as well as the process involving questions on notice.

In considering Senator Ian Macdonald's motion, we looked at whether it was an appropriate device for following matters in this chamber compared with other notices of motion. We have to be very careful in this regard. The purpose was to seek to bring the government to account. Often senators compete in the process of setting down notices of motion. Such competition is healthy but it is important that there be no unnecessary duplication. It is possible to see this motion as a subset of the information sought in Senator Gibson's notice of motion 1315 which asked for all documents relating to the granting of export woodchip licences. That motion was slightly amended before it was passed. It now seeks only to obtain those documents which were exchanged with the Prime Minister. Perhaps the coalition realised that a number of notices of motion were chasing the same rabbit.

I agree with Senator Ian Macdonald in asking for as much transparency as possible in the process. Having taken a careful look at this matter, the Democrats argue strongly that the whole process should be examined by way of an inquiry by a senate standing committee. We envisage that inquiry should be comprehensive and fully targeted at the process which took place—a process which in turn delivered the shemozzle that took place outside this Parliament in recent days.

We believe that an inquiry fully targeted at that process should include examination of all relevant documents. We feel that it should neither duplicate nor omit any information that is necessary to deliver a process that will not continue the annual circus. Such a process has been rightly criticised by the industry, commentators, conservation groups and, most effectively, I believe, by the Democrats—indeed by all except government apologists.

This motion will return some of the information asked for. I understand that Senator Chamarette will be suggesting another date, which we will support. If we are able to support such a proposal, I feel that it would allow proper compilation of the information sought and therefore would have a greater chance of being accurate. We give our reluctant support to this, recognising that it would be inferior to the setting up of a full inquiry into the process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to confirm some statements made in this debate. Obviously the Greens WA support openness and accountability by the government, and particularly in this matter which is of very great concern to us. However, as Senator Ian Macdonald has indicated and is aware, we are concerned that the timing of the motion is unrealistic. We have no desire to rush the rapid assessment process in such a way as to hinder or jeopardise its proper operation.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Bell has said, this motion requests not only a document that exists but seeks the creation of such a document. As to the three conditions sought by Senator Macdonald, I believe that one is impossible of fulfilment until the whole assessment process is complete. To know which of the 509 coupes identified for priority attention are currently being logged in accordance with licence conditions, obviously those coupes have to be visited and listed in terms of current activities. It is a chicken and egg situation; it does not concern a list that simply exists. We can undertake the other two conditions within Senator Ian Macdonald's motion without necessarily making that assessment because those issues are simply matters of fact.

In our view, it is important to allow the due time line to be considered. We have already been informed by the government that this information will become public, but we have been informed that it is not possible to advance the process in order to meet the deadline, namely 5 pm on 8 February as suggested by Senator Ian Macdonald. I move:
Omit "on 8 February 1995" substitute "on 27 February 1995".

SPEECH.PARA: —in other words, on the first day of our next sitting. With that proviso, we will support Senator Ian Macdonald's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not support the motion. I will not take up very much of the Senate's time in debating this matter. However, I wish to point out that, save for the issue of timing, Senator Ian Macdonald's motion asks for no more, in effect, than the statement that the government will be making when this week's assessment is completed. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said in his statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Following consideration by officials from the Departments of DEST, DPIE and PM&C, and consultation with the relevant State Departments, next week Cabinet will consider the status of these coupes, with a view to the statutory decision maker, the Minister for Resources, making a final decision on them.

The process has been clearly outlined. I do not believe the process will be completed by 5 pm Wednesday 8 February, the time specified in Senator Ian Macdonald's motion. I assure Senator Ian Macdonald that the information will be made public as soon as the assessment process is completed.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the other issue raised by Senator Ian Macdonald, I have made two comments in regard to acquittals. One related to a tabling statement in response to a return to order. I said that I had been advised that all four organisations had complied with all relevant acquittal obligations set out in the contracts. On 6 February I also made a comment which may have been in answer to a question without notice. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am satisfied that the reports that have been produced by the councils fulfil the requirements of the grant agreements and that all acquittal procedures have been complied with to date.

I have been advised by the department on this matter that it is completely the standard practice for the department to consider the project completed when the report provided complies with the standards set out in the contract. So that is not when the report is delivered. The acceptance of the report as satisfactory is signified by the department making the final payment. Therefore, the eight-week period from the completion of the project is from that date when the final payment is made. I have already indicated that I am willing to make that timetable available to Senator Ian MacDonald and I am happy to repeat that commitment on the public record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 191, I seek to explain a material part of the speech I made previously which I fear may have been misunderstood by Senator Chamarette and Senator Bell. What I am asking the minor parties is for the coupes that comply with those three preconditions the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) set down in his press release be identified to us. I am not asking for the assessments. Senator Chamarette has just spoken to me privately and said that, to find those coupes, we will need to go through the whole 509.
—That is the process.

—I am not sure that Senator Chamarette is correct in that. The Prime Minister said in his statement—and this is where I think my speech may have been misunderstood—that he will give priority to those coupes that are currently being logged, that have renewed licences and that are not registered as part of the national estate. To make that commitment, as at 2 February when cabinet was considering this, the Prime Minister must have had a list of those.

PARA.TAB: I do not think Senator Chamarette argues that two of those preconditions are easily obtained. It was the third one that Senator Chamarette thought required a bit of extra time. I think Senator Chamarette may have misunderstood my speech, and perhaps Senator Bell as well. The Prime Minister said that he wants to give priority to those coupes that are currently being logged. It does not take very long to find that out. He also said that he wants to give priority to those coupes that had licences renewed in 1994. It does not take long to find that out. He also said that he wants to give priority to those coupes that are not registered as part of the national estate. All of that information is readily available to the Prime Minister. That is why he said in his press release that he wanted to give priority attention to those.

In the event that Senator Bell or Senator Chamarette has misunderstood the point I was making, I want to make it very clear that I am not asking for the assessments. I want to identify those coupes that are currently being logged, that have renewed licences and that are not registered as part of the national estate. SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, this bill proposes the repeal of the Audit Act 1901 and deals with the transitional and consequential matters arising from the repeal of that act and the enactment of proposed replacement legislation, namely, the Auditor-General Act 1994, the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1994 and the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1994.

The Audit Act 1901 is a pervading, operational act that gives flesh to certain basic Constitutional requirements for the raising and spending of money by the Commonwealth; and, to that end, provides a procedural framework for day-to-day financial administration and audit across the whole spectrum of Commonwealth activities. Its repeal and replacement, therefore, has an extensive impact. This bill is intended to permit an orderly transition to the new framework.

PARA.TAB: In particular, this bill provides for the formal transfer, as appropriations, of balances from the Audit Act's existing Fund accounting structure to the new structure established by the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Act; the continuation in office of the person who may be the Auditor-General as at 1 July 1995; the continuation of the existing arrangements for the position of Independent Auditor as auditor of the Australian National Audit Office; the continuation for the time

SPEECH.PARA: being (until regulations under the replacement legislation come into operation) of the current safeguards, as agreed by Parliament, under section 70D of the Audit Act 1901, in relation to the nature of audit and financial reporting disclosures for the security and intelligence agencies; and the making of regulations to cover a range of situations, at a procedural level, should it be needed, to demonstrate legal certainty to other parties so as to support a smooth transition to the new legislative framework—eg, for the continuation of the myriad contractual and other arrangements entered into under the authority of the repealed act, such as operating bank accounts, contract audits in progress, debtors' repayments by instalments etc.

Mr President, the bill's extensive impact, however, can be seen in the Schedule to the bill—in the proposed consequential amendments to the relevant provisions of the more than one hundred other acts which refer in specific ways to the current Audit Act 1901. The proposed amendments will replace those acts' "Audit Act" references with provisions that appropriately link them to the framework of the new financial legislation.

In relation to those Commonwealth Authorities for which the Schedule specifies consequential amendments to their enabling legislation so as to link those authorities to the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies act, it should be noted that the list is not exhaustive. The authorities are only those whose enabling legislation reflects Part XI of the Audit Act 1901. A further transitional bill will be necessary to create the necessary linkages to the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act for the forty or so bodies whose enabling legislation does not reflect Part XI.

Mr President, the introduction of a bill to replace the Audit Act 1901 should be marked as an event of particular significance in the history of the Commonwealth Parliament. Apart from the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, the Audit Act is the oldest law passed by Parliament that is still in operation.

The long title of the Audit Act 1901 describes its purpose to be "An act to make provision for the Collection and Payment of the Public Moneys and the Audit of the Public Accounts and the Protection and Recovery of Public Property. . . ". It has, for 93 years, done the job. This country has been well served by the financial principles established through its provisions, because it has, indeed, kept every Commonwealth Government since Federation financially honest in more than just a rhetorical sense. Over nine decades, there have been countless departmental officials and Auditors, and not a few Parliamentarians, who have confidently looked to the Audit Act 1901 as both the shield and the sword of Commonwealth financial integrity. Mr President, I am sure that none of them, were they here today, could have any doubt that the framework to be created by the legislation that is replacing the Audit Act 1901 will not only preserve that financial integrity, but strengthen it.
In that spirit, Mr President, I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to very briefly canvass some matters which are of great concern to me in relation to Aerospace Technologies of Australia Ltd. It is a serious matter when 23 out of 27 of the Blackhawks at Townsville are not operational and, apparently, a number of them have been in that state since about September.

My concern is focused on a number of matters, but particularly on the question of maintenance by ASTA. In 1992, my colleague Senator Baden Teague asked a question in estimates about the progress being made in the commercialisation of the maintenance of Blackhawk helicopters. He was told that the army had negotiated a maintenance standing offer with ASTA Defence for the highest level of Blackhawk maintenance. That agreement allowed for an estimated 15 R3 services—that is, periodic services—every 500 flying hours to check all major items for airworthiness and associated repairs every year. The standing offer was a firm priced agreement for a period of three years with a two-year extendable option. The estimated total cost per annum was $1.05 million. As I understand it, ASTA maintained five aircraft in the first year, and it was anticipated that it would reach optimum capacity of 15 aircraft a year in early 1993.

The problems being found with the Blackhawks are corrosion and cracking. We have been given various reasons for why these might have occurred. I am concerned as to why it has taken this long for us to be told about this matter and what ASTA's role was in the checking and maintenance. It was up to ASTA to look at the cracking; it was up to ASTA to advise that it was going through spares at an unacceptable rate. It is surely the responsibility of the contractor—as ASTA was—to keep these aircraft in the air. Although I recognise that the army may well have been responsible for field maintenance, these aircraft were to be kept in the air by ASTA Defence.

My special concerns are that only recently I tabled an ombudsman's report in the Senate into the death of an RAAF pilot flying a Nomad. You may well recall that the ombudsman focused very harshly on ASTA's failure to maintain the aircraft which that young pilot was flying. Once again, we found that the board of inquiry had reported on the failure of ASTA to detect cracking by visual inspection, compared to the use of current techniques.

So we have ASTA failing to do its duty by the air force in relation to the Nomads that were on loan to it and that went back to the air force. We now have problems apparently with ASTA not doing its job. Certainly, there are big question marks over the job ASTA is doing under contract for the Department of Defence on the Blackhawks. These are questions which must be answered urgently.

Unfortunately, in relation to the Nomad pilot, ASTA has chosen, despite damning evidence at the board of inquiry which was repeated by the ombudsman, to contest the dead pilot's family in the courts as to its responsibility. We are lucky that we have not had any cases at this stage of army pilots going to their death as a result of failure of checking and maintenance. The Senate must be concerned at the role of ASTA. If it is to be privatised, who is going to queue up to buy an organisation which appears to have let the defence forces of this country down in the maintenance role which it contracts for?

PARA.TAB: We are asked to imagine an Australia where all Australians enjoy perfect health, a long and happy life free from disease and the satisfaction of seeing their highest potential fully expressed in their lives. Imagine an Australia where education is enjoyable for teachers and students alike and where every student and citizen is trained to enjoy a mistake free life. Imagine an Australia free from crime and violence, where every Australian can feel safe and at home wherever they are and whatever they are doing; an Australia in which growth and progress are dynamic, balanced and sustained steadily decade after decade.

These are the components of an invincible Australia. These should perhaps be the ideal goals of this parliament and certainly this chamber. I present to the chamber the discovery of a body of science and technology that is unprecedented in the history of this country and which can achieve these goals to change life in Australia and, in fact, the planet. This science is Maharishi's Vedic science of consciousness.

We would rightly ask: where does this science come from? Vedic science has been developed in its modern form by the enlightened Indian scholar Maharishi Mahesh Yogi. Maharishi is best known for his development of the technique of transcendental meditation and, more recently, for his reconstruction of the traditional system of Vedic medicine known as Maharishi Ayur-Veda. Its importance can be demonstrated by listing four of its best documented achievements. The methods are not philosophical; they are practical. They are fully documented by many hundreds of scientific research studies. Later I will seek leave to table some of this material.

I will give the Senate examples of its results. Firstly, research shows that Vedic health science can almost eliminate the two most devastating diseases of our time—namely, cancer and heart disease. In 1987, a study was published in the journal Psychosomatic Medicine showing that those engaged in the practice of Vedic health techniques have an 86 per cent decrease in heart disease and a 55 per cent decrease in cancer. The study showed a further 50 to 70 per cent decrease in all other illnesses and in hospital admissions and other medical needs. These findings indicate that, if the Australian population had universal access to these programs, over 1,200 lives would be saved every week. The savings in costs are estimated at 50 per cent of today's health budget.

Secondly, Vedic education methods are the only methods that can significantly increase both intelligence and lateral or creative thinking. A large number of studies have demonstrated this in both children and adults. One of the best studies, on high school children, demonstrated not only increases in intelligence and creativity but actually showed that these children rose from average levels of performance to the top five per cent in their state in just a few years. These children are ahead in success, productivity, health, balance and happiness.

The significance to Australia of this systematic development of mental potential, in particular creativity, cannot be overemphasised. Innovation and lateral thinking are the essence of our nation's future. In the past, these high level qualities were thought to be inborn and not capable of cultivation. Today, with Maharishi's Vedic science, it is possible for anyone to enhance creativity. The capacity for brilliant insight can be systematically cultivated to an extraordinary degree. In particular, the Vedic techniques of transcendental meditation, and its more advanced counterpart the TM-Sidhi program, are critical to this achievement. Australia's future depends on the development of creativity and innovation to provide new products and services.

I would dearly love to see this country become the first in the world to achieve a true intelligence development industry—a true brain development industry. We know our future lies in Asia. What can be our best contribution to our neighbours? Surely it must be knowledge and an education.

One country, Cambodia, has already used Australian expertise and finance to create a Vedic university. Cambodia's Maharishi Vedic University specialises in management, medicine, agriculture and architecture. The foreign minister of that country, His Excellency Ung Huot—and I must say that Mr Ung Huot has himself been an Australian citizen and communications technologist for 20 years—has declared Cambodia's Maharishi Vedic University as one of the greatest gifts Australia has given to his country and that this Vedic university has become a shining light of peace and harmony in the Cambodian nation.

The third set of evidence is that scientific research in prisons shows that Vedic methods of rehabilitation can successfully reverse criminal behaviour. The studies show that recidivism rates reduced from as high as 80 per cent to as little as 10 per cent. This means a reduction of at least 80 per cent in the number of repeat offenders in our society. As we know, the cost is at least $40,000 per prisoner per year to maintain them in confinement, let alone the immense cost of damage, injury, detection and apprehension. This means a saving of untold millions of dollars per year in addition to the human cost to criminals, victims and their families.

The fourth set of evidence, and perhaps the most profound, is the scientific research which shows that Maharishi Vedic technologies for government administration can improve the quality of life in society as a whole within a few months. Research findings in that area include: firstly, reduced crime rates; secondly, reduced accidents; thirdly, reduced sickness and hospital admissions; and, fourthly, improved economic performance.

Over 40 studies in the past 20 years indicate that a very small number of people—even a few hundred or a few thousand individuals—in a group using the most advanced Vedic techniques of consciousness, in particular yogic flying, can achieve all of these results within months. Such a group is called a group for a government because it enhances government achievements in these ways. By creating coherence in collective consciousness, the group for a government program enlivens the very basis of governmental success; namely, the collective intelligence of the whole population. It is therefore a true and legitimate administrative strategy. It is one that operates on a level never before adequately addressed by any government.

I refer to the area of crime reduction. The most dramatic demonstration of this technology took place recently in a large, formal and high quality research project conducted in Washington DC in July 1993, some 18 months ago. The Washington study was extremely rigorous. It was supervised by the District of Columbia Council, the District of Columbia Police and an independent board of scholars from local universities. The research team predicted that, with the introduction of the group practice of yogic flying by about 4,000 people, crime would be reduced by 20 per cent. In fact, crime was reduced by 18 per cent within a month. Furthermore, the research showed that, if the project had been continued for 100 days, the reduction in crime would have been at 40 per cent.

I will be seeking leave to table the study which demonstrates this information. I remind the chamber that Washington DC has the highest crime rate in the world, with losses of over $1 billion a year due to crime. A 20 per cent to 40 per cent reduction would be an enormous saving of human life, health and costs.

Washington is not alone. Liverpool in England has achieved similar results on a sustained basis by the same methods. It is estimated that over 130,000 crimes have been prevented in the Merseyside area over three years, resulting in cost savings of #650 million in that time.

The information that I am presenting here, which has been passed to me by the group interested in seeing this information being presented to Australia, is contained in some of the documents that I have. TALK.START.PARA: —Today in the Federal Court at Perth a most important decision was handed down. It involved a case whereby the state of Western Australia and Malcolm Douglas, the proprietor of the Broome Crocodile Farm, took action against the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner. Early last year, the minister had issued a declaration which stopped any further development of the Broome Crocodile Farm due to the development allegedly occurring in an area which was sensitive to local Aboriginal cultural and spiritual interests.

PARA.TAB: The minister did not stop there. He issued a temporary declaration for 30 days. He then extended that for a further 30 days and then imposed a five-year ban on development. During that case, Mr Chaney, a former senator, was appointed as mediator for the parties. During the interim injunctions, mediation and consultation were carried out.

Early last year, I raised many questions with the minister and spoke on this matter many times in this chamber. One of the matters that I raised frequently was the question of natural justice and political accountability. It seems that the Federal Court agrees with me, because today all three declarations were declared invalid. They were declared invalid because of a breach of natural justice and improper process. The court found that the minister has breached his duty under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act, in that he had not pursued proper process in consultation with the state minister in Western Australia. Furthermore, during the proceedings of mediation and consultation, various submissions were made to Mr Chaney without them being revealed to Mr Douglas or the state government. When Mr Chaney's report was forwarded to the minister, there was some suggestion that he did not read all the submissions that had been made to Mr Chaney.

What you had was a minister exercising in the most powerful form an act which stopped the development of a private citizen's business. What is more, that was done without that private citizen having any knowledge of or input into adverse allegations which were being made about him. That is an affront to justice in this country; it is an affront to the rules of natural justice. The court found squarely against the minister in relation to all three declarations. That decision was handed down today by His Honour Justice Carr. I understand that the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Richard Court, has made appropriate comments about the Commonwealth riding roughshod over the state.

In this instance, it is a question of illegal use of power. It is an absolute abuse of power and one which is to be despised. I say to the minister: if you care one jot about conciliation in this country and if you care one jot about working towards the solution of Aboriginal problems in this country, particularly the question of the problem of land ownership, you will not go about it by abusing your powers; you will not go about it by denying private citizens the rules of natural justice; and you will not achieve your ends by improper process.

I welcome the decision by the Federal Court. It vindicates what I have said in this chamber on many occasions. It vindicates the coalition's pursuit of this matter. Senator Campbell and I pursued this with the minister by way of question and comment. One can only question whether Mr Tickner adopted the same bullyboy tactics when he stopped the development of the bridge from Goolwa to Hindmarsh Island in South Australia which sent a private developer bankrupt. In that case, a declaration was made on an ad hoc basis which stopped the building of a bridge.

In the situation that I am referring to, the court has already decided squarely against the minister with some scathing comments as to the process that was adopted. I say to this government: if you are going to exercise your power in this arrogant fashion, then citizens will take you to court and you will be found accountable by the courts of this land. What is more, you will be found even more accountable when it comes to the ballot box.
