TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take note of some matters that have been receiving a lot of attention in the chamber and also in the media. The first of these is the criticisms of the high conservation value forest identification exercise that was conducted by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner. The criticisms that have been made do not hold water and are largely a political exercise designed to remove what little protection the process had given to some areas of high conservation value forests.

PARA.TAB: In my belief, the criticisms were designed, and are designed, to discredit the conservation movement, but they will fail. The reports that were put together by these conservation councils and bodies around the country were based on the work of eminent scientists and were sent to a range of federal and state departments for comment. In many instances, information on the value of areas was drawn from government agencies and industry.

I wish to make a major point which was already made by Senator Faulkner in question time, and I am very glad of that. It seems to have been overlooked in the public debate. When there have been attempts to discredit the coupes that have been set aside for protection by making statements such as that they contain airstrips and areas that have already been logged, there is a failure to understand that the boundaries of coupes and forests blocks are set by state agencies.

The conservationists were not able to draw boundaries around areas of high conservation value. Consequently, coupes, compartments or blocks can obviously contain some form of disturbance. But this does not mean that other parts of the defined area do not have high conservation value.

The response to these criticisms has been very ably expressed by the National Forest Summit, which met on 4 February 1995. For the convenience of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate the two-page response to those criticisms, which is a very enlightening document.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: HOW ACCURATE ARE INDUSTRY CRITICISMS OF THE HIGH CONSERVATION VALUE FOREST IDENTIFICATION EXERCISE CONDUCTED BY FAULKNER?
A position paper by the National Forest Summit—4 February 1995

The forest industries and some politicians are at present claiming that some areas on the list of high conservation value coupes and compartments presented by the Prime Minister from Mr Faulkner's original list are not of high conservation value. Why is this misleading?

Most claims of this sort rely on the fact that a coupe or compartment contains some form of disturbance, such as an old air strip, quarry or plantation. This ignores the very simple fact that a coupe or compartment can contain a small area of non-high conservation value and still contain large areas of high conservation value forest. In such cases, a small area of low conservation value is being used to claim that a large area of high conservation value is of low conservation value. People making claims of this sort are either simply naive or are not scientifically literate.

The industry will also assert that many of these areas have been logged before, and ask you to make the assumption that this means these areas should not be on the high conservation list. What has to be realised is that within a set area, such as a coupe or compartment, it is possible to log part of the area, with the remaining forest still untouched. This is in fact common practice. It is a silly leap of logic that dictates this means that the untouched forest is also of low conservation value. The recommendations for protection were based on the value of the unlogged forest within such compartments, not the patches of regrowth. It is also possible that some coupes or compartments have been selectively harvested many decades ago. Those practices involved the removal of low numbers of carefully selected trees, and is very different to the far more destructive logging practices of today. While this past selective logging may have caused some damage to some of the area's conservation values, in many cases they still represent the last examples of those forest communities.

Another interesting piece of misdirection is the insinuation that this exercise was meant to be the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories' (DEST) definitive exercise on the identification of areas of high conservation value. This claim is incorrect, but it is used in an attempt to make the exercise appear to be of a low standard by comparing it to other larger projects. In fact this exercise was never meant to be the end of the process, but simply an interim measure to prevent further loss of high conservation value forests until fully adequate surveys of all forest values could be completed.

What critics have further failed to realise is that the exercise surveyed a wide range of conservation values beyond just old growth, including wilderness, World Heritage, endangered species, water catchment values and Aboriginal values. It is essential that when assessing an area all these values are considered.
Such criticisms in no way blemish the credibility of Faulkner's study. They are simply a desperate attempt to hold on to the high conservation value forests for logging and woodchipping.
A list is included below of some examples of industry confusion on the issue:

Compartment 2331 in Glenbog State Forest in the South East of NSW was reported in "The Australian" (18-19/1/95) as being a compartment that had been logged twice before and contained much regrowth. However, being 200 hectares in size, it also contains a significant area of old growth forest and is an important catchment supplying water to the dairy industry around Bega.

It was reported in the Australian today that compartment 32 in Stewarts Brook State Forest in NE NSW is not high conservation value because it includes camping areas and a tip. They have failed to recognise that this compartment contains significant populations of two nationally vulnerable plants, a very significant swamp, and is unlogged. It is important not just for its natural values but also as a significant area for recrea tion.

Industry maintains that the presence of an airstrip in compartment 191 in MacPherson State Forest in NE NSW means that the surrounding forests have no conservation values. They have failed to recognise that this compartment is in the Warre Warren Aboriginal Place which is listed on the National Estate, and that two nationally vulnerable plants species and one nationally endangered animal species have been recorded in the vicinity.

In Victoria, claims of pine plantations and other disturbances have not even been substantiated by industry or Government forestry agencies. As the information used by conservation groups in their original recommendations to Mr Faulkner were sourced from material provided by these very agencies, it would appear that any errors in the identification process were their own fault and so their criticisms are directed at themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. My first point is that the criticism of the boundaries and what is contained within them is not at all valid if it is intended to cast aspersions on the very important process that was undertaken by the conservation movement when it was asked for advice by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I would like to relate the process that went on in Western Australia. In Western Australia, the list was provided by the Conservation Council and was not in any sense an ambit claim. Many areas, including heritage-listed areas, were not incorporated because of the lack of information available. The Conservation Council put forward a compromise list of 29 forest blocks. Senator Faulkner recommended that 21 of them be protected. The Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) listed two. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has raised that number to 12. I might add that that fails to protect them, because access to them has not been protected by that response. Roads are being made and disturbance is continuing within those areas.

CALM has scheduled 75 blocks for logging in the central and southern forest regions of Western Australia in 1995. Mr Keating identified only 12 for the temporary protection that may be afforded by his rapid assessment process. So we believe it is very serious that the process fails to protect even those areas that are supposedly being looked at.

A concern in Western Australia is that the state environment minister, Mr Kevin Minson, has ordered Western Australian loggers to ignore the ban on logging in the Rosa forest block south of Nannup, which was one of the areas identified by Mr Keating. Yesterday CALM informed the conservationists from the local community of Northcliffe that they would stop work on a logging super-highway through Jane Forest near the town. Today CALM contractors were again felling trees to make way for the road with little regard for the protesters who are trying to protect that area of forest.

My second point relates to a passing comment of Senator Abetz earlier today. Senator Abetz dismissed the phrase that forests could be lost forever. He made a joke of it and said that forests could only be lost if the areas were dynamited and destroyed totally so that nothing could grow on them. I must put on the public record and inform Senator Abetz that he is clearly displaying his ignorance as to the difference between forests and trees and the degree to which forests can be affected by logging.

A forest is much more than an area where trees grow. I particularly want to differentiate it from regrowth, or what grows after clear-felling has taken place. Forests have biodiversity. They have different species of trees and foliage growing in them. They form a complete ecosystem and provide habitat and a range of flora and fauna that makes them irreplaceable once they are logged.

There is a very beautiful area known as the 100-year old forest near Boranup in south-west Western Australia. Many people have been there. I have really enjoyed it myself. It took some education for me to realise that it is a karri forest that is the result of intensive logging. Instead of a real old-growth forest with diversity and a complete ecosystem being created, a monoculture has been produced. Because it is 100 years old, it is very beautiful and definitely evidence to support the argument which people often use that `forests or trees grow back'.

Anybody who wanders through that forest will notice that in some places the very beautiful, tall karri trees are close together. On one walk, I noticed that four trees growing together in a very outstanding way were all growing out of one stump. So, in a sense, that forest is not the forest that was logged. It is a different forest that is 100 years old and which has a value of its own.

We are trying to protect—this is what the debate is about—those old-growth areas of forest that still remain. Those high conservation value forests that still remain need to be protected in a way that that area was not. It is not a question of their not growing again. Cleared land, which produces salinity and water catchment problems, will sometimes not grow again. We are not saying that the forest industry will prevent trees growing; we are saying that the forests that we so prize in our community will be lost forever. New growth will occur, but it will not be the same. It is an irretrievable position. That is why it is very important that the federal and state governments do not lose the political will, which they have not demonstrated so far but which the community is demanding of them, to protect those areas.

Because of the shortage of time, I seek leave to incorporate a two-page statement by seven leading forest ecologists calling for the better protection of native forests and defining the process and their understanding of it.

SPEECH.PARA: AUSTRALIAS LEADING FOREST ECOLOGISTS CALL FOR BETTER PROTECTION OF NATIVE FORESTS

Responding to the continuing debate over the future of the export woodchip industry, some of Australias leading forest ecologists have called upon the Commonwealth and State Governments and all parts of the Australian community to act decisively to protect the nations remaining old growth eucalypt forests and other forests vital for the long term conservation of biological diversity.

The initiation of an export woodchip industry has led to the increased logging of Australias forests. This increased logging is largely due to clearfelling and is concentrated in forests which are largely undisturbed and contain large mature trees. Many plants and animals depend on large mature trees for essential resources such as food and shelter. Such species are restricted to forests that have had little or not disturbance from unnatural processes such as clearfelling. The impact on plants and animals living on the ground is also of particular concern.

Over half of our native forests have been permanently cleared since European occupation, and the present rate of forest clearance in many Australian regions well exceeds that observed in the Amazon Basin. The current conservation reserve system is inadequate and fails to protect many distinct types of old growth forest and biodiversity. Australian Governments and the community must take action if these unique ecosystems and forest biodiversity are to be conserved.

Australias forests will never be managed sustainably if Governments continue with the present piecemeal approach of assessing individual compartments and coupes. Proper planning and management requires the comprehensive assessment of forests at a regional level. Australian Governments gave a commitment in the National Forest Policy Statement to undertake regional assessments so as to ensure the adequate protection of wilderness and old growth forests. This commitment must be followed through.

In the absence of comprehensive regional assessments, the most prudent course of action for the Commonwealth and State Governments to take is to immediately suspend logging in the 1300 compartments nominated by the Federal Environment Minister, Senator John Faulkner. The process by which Senator Faulkners department determined the 1300 areas likely to have high conservation values was a reasonable and valid process. These 1300 areas represent only a proportion of the native forest scheduled for logging in 1995. The conservation values of these areas, and particularly the 509 compartments to be fast-tracked, must now be determined by a thorough and independent scientific review involving institutions such as CSIRO and universities. Because of the known and potential ecological significance of these forest areas, this review must draw upon the best available information and will require collaboration between governments, scientists and the community.
There is no sense in logging the forests before they have been properly assessed.

We believe that there are genuine concerns on all sides of this debate which should not be overlooked. Political solutions are not solutions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 5 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that, only as recently as the week beginning 27 November 1994, members of the Forest Information Network documented no less than five breaches of prescription in compartment 13 of Croobyar State Forest with a district forester.
(2) Is the Minister aware that these breaches included the logging of three habitat trees with obvious hollows and two examples of logging within a prescribed filter strip.
(3) What action will be taken if breaches of conditions attached to the granting of woodchip licences by forestry activities can be proved.
(4) Will the Minister revoke woodchip licences if it can be demonstrated that material sourced for woodchipping has been taken in breach of licence conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) State Forests of New South Wales has advised that the 5 alleged breaches related to the felling of two trees in an owl prescription zone and the felling of three trees into a prescribed filter strip. I understand that the trees felled into the filter strip were accidentally hit by other trees which were being harvested.

(3) Where export licence conditions have been breached a licence can be revoked or financial penalties applied. Specifically in the case raised by the honourable senator, State Forests of New South Wales have investigated the alleged breaches and have concluded that there were three breaches of logging prescriptions. I understand that State Forests of New South Wales is taking disciplinary action in relation to these breaches. I understand that the State's Environment Protection Agency is also investigating whether the breaches contravene the pollution licence issued to State Forests of New South Wales. Appropriate follow up action consistent with the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations under the Export Control Act 1982 will be taken in all cases where breaches have been demonstrated.

(4) The matters raised by the honourable senator in questions 1 and 2 relate primarily to sawlog operations in 1994 and given the action described above I do not believe action is required in relation Harris Daishowa's 1995 licence.

I announced in December that the 1995 export licences contained tough new conditions to protect the environment. I also announced that measures are being developed to improve monitoring of environmental conditions in woodchip export licences. I will be increasing the intensity of the Commonwealth's monitoring of compliance with licence conditions. I will require the Chief Executive Officer of each company holding a licence to provide a report to me at the end of the year of the company's compliance with the conditions of the licence.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 7 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What mechanism or procedure exists to ensure that when minor species sawlogs are to be exported under Commonwealth licence the Minister is satisfied that there is no domestic demand for logs.
(2) What volume of minor species sawlog has been exported as woodchips from Tasmanian forests since 1 July 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commonwealth has not issued a licence for the export of minor species sawlogs from Tasmania.

I am advised that all sawlogs of the minor species are sold to sawmills. State approved timber classification officers inspect logs prior to chipping to ensure sawlogs have not been incorrectly classified. Forestry Tasmania also has a system of random checks to ensure a high standard of log classification.
(2) The volume of minor species pulpwood exported from Tasmania in the last half of 1994 is not recorded separately by the Commonwealth from other pulpwood exports.
As the value of sawlogs is higher than that of pulplogs there is an economic incentive for managers of wood production forests to maximise sawlog recovery rather than convert sawlogs to woodchips.
